speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Escalus.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: My Lord.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Of Gouernment, the properties to vnfold,
Would ſeeme in me t’ aﬀeƈt ſpeech & diſcourſe,
Since I am put to know, that your owne Science
Exceedes (in that) the liſts of all aduice
My ſtrength can giue you: Then no more remaines
But that, to your ſuﬃciency, as your worth is able,
And let them worke: The nature of our People,
Our Cities Inſtitutions, and the Termes
For Common Iuſtice, y’are as pregnant in
As Art, and praƈtiſe, hath inriched any
That we remember: There is our Commiſſion,
From which, we would not haue you warpe; call hither,
I ſay, bid come before vs Angelo:
What ﬁgure of vs thinke you, he will beare.
For you muſt know, we haue with ſpeciall ſoule
Eleƈted him our abſence to ſupply;
Lent him our terror, dreſt him with our loue,
And giuen his Deputation all the Organs
Of our owne powre: What thinke you of it?

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: If any in Vienna be of worth
To vndergoe ſuch ample grace, and honour,
It is Lord Angelo.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Looke where he comes.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Alwayes obedient to your Graces will,
I come to know your pleaſure.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Angelo:
There is a kinde of Charaƈter in thy life,
That to th’ obſeruer, doth thy hiſtory
Fully vnfold: Thy ſelfe, and thy belongings
Are not thine owne ſo proper, as to waſte
Thy ſelfe vpon thy vertues; they on thee:
Heauen doth with vs, as we, with Torches doe,
Not light them for themſelues: For if our vertues
Did not goe forth of vs, ’twere all alike
As if we had them not: Spirits are not ﬁnely tonch’d,
But to ﬁne iſſues: nor nature neuer lends
The ſmalleſt ſcruple of her excellence,
But like a thrifty goddeſſe, ſhe determines
Her ſelfe the glory of a creditour,
Both thanks, and vſe; but I do bend my ſpeech
To one that can my part in him aduertiſe;
Hold therefore Angelo:
In our remoue, be thou at full, our ſelfe:
Mortallitie and Mercie in Vienna
Liue in thy tongue, and heart: Old Eſcalus
Though ﬁrſt in queſtion, is thy ſecondary.
Take thy Commiſſion.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Now good my Lord
Let there be ſome more teſt, made of my mettle,
Before ſo noble, and ſo great a ﬁgure
Be ſtamp’t vpon it.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: No more euaſion:
We haue with a leauen’d, and prepared choice
Proceeded to you; therefore take your honors:
Our haſte from hence is of ſo quicke condition,
That it prefers it ſelfe, and leaues vnqueſtion’d
Matters of needfull value: We ſhall write to you
As time, and our concernings ſhall importune,
How it goes with vs, and doe looke to know
What doth befall you here. So fare you well:
To th’ hopefull execution doe I leaue you,
Of your Commiſſions.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Yet giue leaue (my Lord,)
That we may bring you ſomething on the way.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: My haſte may not admit it,
Nor neede you (on mine honor) haue to doe
With any ſcruple: your ſcope is as mine owne,
So to inforce, or qualiﬁe the Lawes
As to your ſoule ſeemes good: Giue me your hand,
Ile priuily away: I loue the people,
But doe not like to ſtage me to their eyes:
Though it doe well, I doe not relliſh well
Their lowd applauſe, and Aues vehement:
Nor doe I thinke the man of ſafe diſcretion
That do’s aﬀeƈt it. Once more fare you well.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: The heauens giue ſafety to your purpoſes.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Lead forth, and bring you backe in happi-
neſſe.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: I thanke you, fare you well.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: I ſhall deſire you, Sir, to giue me leaue
To haue free ſpeech with you; and it concernes me
To looke into the bottome of my place:
A powre I haue, but of what ſtrength and nature,
I am not yet inſtruƈted.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: ’Tis ſo with me: Let vs with-draw together,
And we may ſoone our ſatisfaƈtion haue
Touching that point.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Ile wait vpon your honor.

scene.stagedir: Enter Lucio, and two other Gentlemen.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: If the Duke, with the other Dukes, come not to
compoſition with the King of Hungary, why then all the
Dukes fall vpon the King.

speech.speaker: 1. Gent.
speech.line: Heauen grant vs its peace, but not the King
of Hungaries.

speech.speaker: 2. Gent.
speech.line: Amen.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Thou conclud’ſt like the Sanƈtimonious Pirat,
that went to ſea with the ten Commandements, but
ſcrap’d one out of the Table.

speech.speaker: 2. Gent.
speech.line: Thou ſhalt not Steale?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I, that he raz’d.

speech.speaker: 1. Gent.
speech.line: Why? ’twas a commandement, to command
the Captaine and all the reſt from their funƈtions: they
put forth to ſteale: There’s not a Souldier of vs all, that
in the thankſ-giuing before meate, do ralliſh the petition
well, that praies for peace.

speech.speaker: 2. Gent.
speech.line: I neuer heard any Souldier diſlike it.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I beleeue thee: for I thinke thou neuer was’t
where Grace was ſaid.

speech.speaker: 2. Gent.
speech.line: No? a dozen times at leaſt.

speech.speaker: 1. Gent.
speech.line: What? In meeter?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: In any proportion. or in any language.

speech.speaker: 1. Gent.
speech.line: I thinke, or in any Religion.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I, why not? Grace, is Grace, deſpight of all con-
trouerſie: as for example; Thou thy ſelfe art a wicked
villaine, deſpight of all Grace.

speech.speaker: 1. Gent.
speech.line: Well: there went but a paire of ſheeres be-
tweene vs.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I grant: as there may betweene the Liſts, and
the Veluet. Thou art the Liſt.

speech.speaker: 1. Gent.
speech.line: And thou the Veluet; thou art good veluet;
thou’rt a three pild-peece I warrant thee: I had as liefe
be a Lyſt of an Engliſh Kerſey, as be pil’d, as thou art
pil’d, for a French Veluet. Do I ſpeake feelingly now?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I thinke thou do’ſt: and indeed with moſt pain-
full feeling of thy ſpeech: I will, out of thine owne con-
feſſion, learne to begin thy health; but, whilſt I liue for-
get to drinke after thee.

speech.speaker: 1. Gen.
speech.line: I think I haue done my ſelfe wrong, haue I not?

speech.speaker: 2. Gent.
speech.line: Yes, that thou haſt; whether thou art tainted,
or free.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Behold, behold, where Madam Mitigation comes.
I haue purchaſ’d as many diſeaſes vnder her Roofe,
As come to

speech.speaker: 2. Gent.
speech.line: To what, I pray?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Iudge.

speech.speaker: 2. Gent.
speech.line: To three thouſand Dollours a yeare.

speech.speaker: 1. Gent.
speech.line: I, and more.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: A French crowne more.

speech.speaker: 1. Gent.
speech.line: Thou art alwayes ﬁguring diſeaſes in me; but
thou art full of error, I am ſound.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Nay, not (as one would ſay) healthy: but ſo
ſound, as things that are hollow; thy bones are hollow;
Impiety has made a feaſt of thee.

speech.speaker: 1. Gent.
speech.line: How now, which of your hips has the moſt
profound Ciatica?

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Well, well: there’s one yonder arreſted, and
carried to priſon, was worth ﬁue thouſand of you all.

speech.speaker: 2. Gent.
speech.line: Who’s that I pray’thee?

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Marry Sir, that’s Claudio, Signior Claudio.

speech.speaker: 1. Gent.
speech.line: Claudio to priſon? ’tis not ſo.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Nay, but I know ’tis ſo: I ſaw him arreſted:
ſaw him carried away: and which is more, within theſe
three daies his head to be chop’d oﬀ.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: But, after all this fooling, I would not haue it ſo:
Art thou ſure of this?

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: I am too ſure of it: and it is for getting Madam
Iulietta with childe.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Beleeue me this may be: he promis’d to meete
me two howres ſince, and he was euer preciſe in promiſe
keeping.

speech.speaker: 2. Gent.
speech.line: Beſides you know, it drawes ſomthing neere
to the ſpeech we had to ſuch a purpoſe.

speech.speaker: 1. Gent.
speech.line: But moſt of all agreeing with the proclamatiō.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Away: let’s goe learne the truth of it.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Thus, what with the war; what with the ſweat,
what with the gallowes, and what with pouerty, I am
Cuſtom-ſhrunke. How now? what’s the newes with
you.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Yonder man is carried to priſon.

speech.speaker: Baw.
speech.line: Well: what has he done?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: A Woman.

speech.speaker: Baw.
speech.line: But what’s his oﬀence?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Groping for Trowts, in a peculiar Riuer.

speech.speaker: Baw.
speech.line: What? is there a maid with child by him?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: No: but there’s a woman with maid by him:
you haue not heard of the proclamation, haue you?

speech.speaker: Baw.
speech.line: What proclamation, man?

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: All howſes in the Suburbs of Vienna muſt bee
pluck’d downe.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: And what ſhall become of thoſe in the Citie?

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: They ſhall ſtand for ſeed: they had gon down
to, but that a wiſe Burger put in for them.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: But ſhall all our houſes of reſort in the Sub-
urbs be puld downe?

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: To the ground, Miſtris.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Why heere’s a change indeed in the Common-
wealth: what ſhall become of me?

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: Come: feare not you; good Counſellors lacke
no Clients: though you change your place, you neede
not change your Trade: Ile bee your Tapſter ſtill; cou-
rage, there will bee pitty taken on you; you that haue
worne your eyes almoſt out in the ſeruice, you will bee
conſidered.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: What’s to doe heere, Thomas Tapſter? let’s
withdraw?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Here comes Signior Claudio, led by the Prouoſt
to priſon: and there’s Madam Iuliet.

scene.stagedir: Enter Prouoſt, Claudio, Iuliet, Oﬃcers, Lucio, & 2. Gent.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Fellow, why do’ſt thou ſhow me thus to th’ world?
Beare me to priſon, where I am committed.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: I do it not in euill diſpoſition,
But from Lord Angelo by ſpeciall charge.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Thus can the demy-god (Authority)
Make vs pay downe, for our oﬀence, by waight
The words of heauen; on whom it will, it will,
On whom it will not (ſoe) yet ſtill ’tis iuſt.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Why how now Claudio? whence comes this reſtraint.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: From too much liberty, (my Lucio) Liberty
As ſurfet is the father of much faſt,
So euery Scope by the immoderate vſe
Turnes to reſtraint: Our Natures doe purſue
Like Rats that rauyn downe their proper Bane,
A thirſty euill, and when we drinke, we die.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: If I could ſpeake ſo wiſely vnder an arreſt, I
would ſend for certaine of my Creditors: and yet, to ſay
the truth, I had as lief haue the foppery of freedome, as
the mortality of impriſonment: what’s thy oﬀence,
Claudio?

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: What (but to ſpeake of) would oﬀend againe.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: What, is’t murder?

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Lecherie?

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Call it ſo.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Away, Sir, you muſt goe.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: One word, good friend:
Lucio, a word with you.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: A hundred:
If they’ll doe you any good: Is Lechery ſo look’d after?

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Thus ſtands it with me: vpon a true contraƈt
I got poſſeſſion of Iulietas bed,
You know the Lady, ſhe is faſt my wife,
Saue that we doe the denunciation lacke
Of outward Order. This we came not to,
Onely for propogation of a Dowre
Remaining in the Coﬀer of her friends,
From whom we thought it meet to hide our Loue
Till Time had made them for vs. But it chances
The ſtealth of our moſt mutuall entertainment
With Charaƈter too groſſe, is writ on Iuliet.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: With childe, perhaps?

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Vnhappely, euen ſo.
And the new Deputie, now for the Duke,
Whether it be the fault and glimpſe of newnes,
Or whether that the body publique, be
A horſe whereon the Gouernor doth ride,
Who newly in the Seate, that it may know
He can command; lets it ſtrait feele the ſpur:
Whether the Tirranny be in his place,
Or in his Eminence that ﬁlls it vp
I ſtagger in: But this new Gouernor
Awakes me all the inrolled penalties
Which haue (like vn-ſcowr’d Armor) hung by th’ wall
So long, that ninteene Zodiacks haue gone round,
And none of them beene worne; and for a name
Now puts the drowſie and negleƈted Aƈt
Freſhly on me: ’tis ſurely for a name.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I warrant it is: And thy head ſtands ſo tickle on
thy ſhoulders, that a milke-maid, if ſhe be in loue, may
ſigh it oﬀ: Send after the Duke, and appeale to him.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: I haue done ſo, but hee’s not to be found.
I pre’thee (Lucio) doe me this kinde ſeruice:
This day, my ſiſter ſhould the Cloyſter enter,
And there receiue her approbation.
Acquaint her with the danger of my ſtate,
Implore her, in my voice, that ſhe make friends
To the ſtriƈt deputie: bid her ſelfe aſſay him,
I haue great hope in that: for in her youth
There is a prone and ſpeechleſſe dialeƈt,
Such as moue men: beſide, ſhe hath proſperous Art
When ſhe will play with reaſon, and diſcourſe,
And well ſhe can perſwade.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I pray ſhee may; aſwell for the encouragement
of the like, which elſe would ſtand vnder greeuous im-
poſition: as for the enioying of thy life, who I would be
ſorry ſhould bee thus fooliſhly loſt, at a game of ticke-
tacke: Ile to her.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: I thanke you good friend Lucio.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Within two houres.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Come Oﬃcer, away.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: No: holy Father, throw away that thought,
Beleeue not that the dribling dart of Loue
Can pierce a compleat boſome: why, I deſire thee
To giue me ſecret harbour, hath a purpoſe
More graue, and wrinkled, then the aimes, and ends
Of burning youth.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: May your Grace ſpeake of it?

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: My holy Sir, none better knowes then you
How I haue euer lou’d the life remoued
And held in idle price, to haunt aſſemblies
Where youth, and coſt, witleſſe brauery keepes.
I haue deliuerd to Lord Angelo
(A man of ſtriƈture and ﬁrme abſtinence)
My abſolute power, and place here in Vienna,
And he ſuppoſes me trauaild to Poland,
(For ſo I haue ſtrewd it in the common eare)
And ſo it is receiu’d: Now (pious Sir)
You will demand of me, why I do this.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: Gladly, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: We haue ſtriƈt Statutes, and moſt biting Laws,
(The needfull bits and curbes to headſtrong weedes,)
Which for this foureteene yeares, we haue let ſlip,
Euen like an ore-growne Lyon in a Caue
That goes not out to prey: Now, as fond Fathers,
Hauing bound vp the threatning twigs of birch,
Onely to ſticke it in their childrens ſight,
For terror, not to vſe: in time the rod
More mock’d, then fear’d: ſo our Decrees,
Dead to inﬂiƈtion, to themſelues are dead,
And libertie, plucks Iuſtice by the noſe;
The Baby beates the Nurſe, and quite athwart
Goes all decorum.

speech.speaker: Fri.
speech.line: It reſted in your Grace
To vnlooſe this tyde-vp Iuſtice, when you pleaſ’d:
And it in you more dreadfull would haue ſeem’d
Then in Lord Angelo.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: I doe feare: too dreadfull:
Sith ’twas my fault, to giue the people ſcope,
’Twould be my tirrany to ſtrike and gall them,
For what I bid them doe: For, we bid this be done
When euill deedes haue their permiſſiue paſſe,
And not the puniſhment: therefore indeede (my father)
I haue on Angelo impos’d the oﬃce,
Who may in th’ ambuſh of my name, ſtrike home,
And yet, my nature neuer in the ſight
To do in ſlander: And to behold his ſway
I will, as ’twere a brother of your Order,
Viſit both Prince, and People: Therefore I pre’thee
Supply me with the habit, and inſtruƈt me
How I may formally in perſon beare
Like a true Frier: Moe reaſons for this aƈtion
At our more leyſure, ſhall I render you;
Onely, this one: Lord Angelo is preciſe,
Stands at a guard with Enuie: ſcarce confeſſes
That his blood ﬂowes: or that his appetite
Is more to bread then ſtone: hence ſhall we ſee
If power change purpoſe: what our Seemers be.

scene.stagedir: Enter Iſabell and Franciſca a Nun.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: And haue you Nuns no farther priuiledges?

speech.speaker: Nun.
speech.line: Are not theſe large enough?

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Yes truely; I ſpeake not as deſiring more,
But rather wiſhing a more ſtriƈt reſtraint
Vpon the Siſterhood, the Votariſts of Saint Clare.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Hoa? peace be in this place.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Who’s that which cals?

speech.speaker: Nun.
speech.line: It is a mans voice: gentle Iſabella
Turne you the key, and know his buſineſſe of him;
You may; I may not: you are yet vnſworne:
When you haue vowd, you muſt not ſpeake with men,
But in the preſence of the Prioreſſe;
Then if you ſpeake, you muſt not ſhow your face;
Or if you ſhow your face, you muſt not ſpeake.
He cals againe: I pray you anſwere him.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Peace and proſperitie: who is’t that cals?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Haile Virgin, (if you be) as thoſe cheeke-Roſes
Proclaime you are no leſſe: can you ſo ſteed me,
As bring me to the ſight of Iſabella,
A Nouice of this place, and the faire Siſter
To her vnhappie brother Claudio?

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Why her vnhappy Brother? Let me aske,
The rather for I now muſt make you know
I am that Iſabella, and his Siſter.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Gentle & faire: your Brother kindly greets you;
Not to be weary with you; he’s in priſon.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Woe me; for what?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: For that, which if my ſelfe might be his Iudge,
He ſhould receiue his puniſhment, in thankes:
He hath got his friend with childe.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Sir, make me not your ſtorie.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: ’Tis true; I would not, though ’tis my familiar ſin,
With Maids to ſeeme the Lapwing, and to ieſt
Tongue, far from heart: play with all Virgins ſo:
I hold you as a thing en-skied, and ſainted,
By your renouncement, an imortall ſpirit
And to be talk’d with in ſincerity,
As with a Saint.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: You doe blaſpheme the good, in mocking me.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Doe not beleeue it: fewnes, and truth; tis thus,
Your brother, and his louer haue embrac’d;
As thoſe that feed, grow full: as bloſſoming Time
That from the ſeednes, the bare fallow brings
To teeming foyſon: euen ſo her plenteous wombe
Expreſſeth his full Tilth, and husbandry.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Some one with childe by him? my coſen Iuliet?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Is ſhe your coſen?

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Adoptedly, as ſchoole-maids change their names
By vaine, though apt aﬀeƈtion.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: She it is.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Oh, let him marry her.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: This is the point.
The Duke is very ſtrangely gone from hence;
Bore many gentlemen (my ſelfe being one)
In hand, and hope of aƈtion: but we doe learne,
By thoſe that know the very Nerues of State,
His giuing-out, were of an inﬁnite diſtance
From his true meant deſigne: vpon his place,
(And with full line of his authority)
Gouernes Lord Angelo; A man, whoſe blood
Is very ſnow-broth: one, who neuer feeles
The wanton ſtings, and motions of the ſence;
But doth rebate, and blunt his naturall edge
With proﬁts of the minde: Studie, and faſt
He (to giue feare to vſe, and libertie,
Which haue, for long, run-by the hideous law,
As Myce, by Lyons) hath pickt out an aƈt,
Vnder whoſe heauy ſence, your brothers life
Fals into forfeit: he arreſts him on it,
And followes cloſe the rigor of the Statute
To make him an example: all hope is gone,
Vnleſſe you haue the grace, by your faire praier
To ſoften Angelo: And that’s my pith of buſineſſe
’Twixt you, and your poore brother.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Doth he ſo,
Seeke his life?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Has cenſur’d him already,
And as I heare, the Prouoſt hath a warrant
For’s execution.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Alas: what poore
Abilitie’s in me, to doe him good.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Aſſay the powre you haue.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: My power? alas, I doubt.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Our doubts are traitors
And makes vs looſe the good we oft might win,
By fearing to attempt: Goe to Lord Angelo
And let him learne to know, when Maidens ſue
Men giue like gods: but when they weepe and kneele,
All their petitions, are as freely theirs
As they themſelues would owe them.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Ile ſee what I can doe.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: But ſpeedily.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: I will about it ſtrait;
No longer ſtaying, but to giue the Mother
Notice of my aﬀaire: I humbly thanke you:
Commend me to my brother: ſoone at night
Ile ſend him certaine word of my ſucceſſe.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I take my leaue of you.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Good ſir, adieu.

scene.stagedir: Enter Angelo, Eſcalus, and ſeruants, Iuſtice.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: We muſt not make a ſcar-crow of the Law,
Setting it vp to feare the Birds of prey,
And let it keepe one ſhape, till cuſtome make it
Their pearch, and not their terror.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: I, but yet
Let vs be keene, and rather cut a little
Then fall, and bruiſe to death: alas, this gentleman
Whom I would ſaue, had a moſt noble father,
Let but your honour know
(Whom I beleeue to be moſt ſtrait in vertue)
That in the working of your owne aﬀeƈtions,
Had time coheard with Place, or place with wiſhing,
Or that the reſolute aƈting of our blood
Could haue attaind th’ eﬀeƈt of your owne purpoſe,
Whether you had not ſometime in your life
Er’d in this point, which now you cenſure him,
And puld the Law vpon you.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: ’Tis one thing to be tempted (Eſcalus)
Another thing to fall: I not deny
The Iury paſſing on the Priſoners life
May in the ſworne-twelue haue a thiefe, or two
Guiltier then him they try; what’s open made to Iuſtice,
That Iuſtice ceizes; What knowes the Lawes
That theeues do paſſe on theeues? ’Tis very pregnant,
The Iewell that we ﬁnde, we ſtoope, and take’t,
Becauſe we ſee it; but what we doe not ſee,
We tread vpon, and neuer thinke of it.
You may not ſo extenuate his oﬀence,
For I haue had ſuch faults; but rather tell me
When I, that cenſure him, do ſo oﬀend,
Let mine owne Iudgement patterne out my death,
And nothing come in partiall. Sir, he muſt dye.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Be it as your wiſedome will.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Where is the Prouoſt?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Here if it like your honour.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: See that Claudio
Be executed by nine to morrow morning,
Bring him his Confeſſor, let him be prepar’d,
For that’s the vtmoſt of his pilgrimage.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Well: heauen forgiue him; and forgiue vs all:

line.italic: Some riſe by ſinne, and ſome by vertue fall:

speech.line: Some run from brakes of Ice, and anſwere none,
And ſome condemned for a fault alone.

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: Come, bring them away: if theſe be good peo-
ple in a Common-weale, that doe nothing but vſe their
abuſes in common houſes, I know no law: bring them
away.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: How now Sir, what’s your name? And what’s
the matter?

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: If it pleaſe your honour, I am the poore Dukes
Conſtable, and my name is Elbow; I doe leane vpon Iu-
ſtice Sir, and doe bring in here before your good honor,
two notorious Benefaƈtors.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Benefaƈtors? Well: What Benefaƈtors are they?
Are they not Malefaƈtors?

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: If it pleaſe your honour, I know not well what
they are: But preciſe villaines they are, that I am ſure of,
and void of all prophanation in the world, that good
Chriſtians ought to haue.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: This comes oﬀ well: here’s a wiſe Oﬃcer.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Goe to: What quality are they of? Elbow is
your name?
Why do’ſt thou not ſpeake Elbow?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: He cannot Sir: he’s out at Elbow.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: What are you Sir?

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: He Sir: a Tapſter Sir: parcell Baud: one that
ſerues a bad woman: whoſe houſe Sir was (as they ſay)
pluckt downe in the Suborbs: and now ſhee profeſſes a
hot-houſe; which, I thinke is a very ill houſe too.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: How know you that?

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: My wife Sir? whom I deteſt before heauen, and
your honour.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: How? thy wife?

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: I Sir: whom I thanke heauen is an honeſt wo-
man.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Do’ſt thou deteſt her therefore?

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: I ſay ſir, I will deteſt my ſelfe alſo, as well as ſhe,
that this houſe, if it be not a Bauds houſe, it is pitty of her
life, for it is a naughty houſe.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: How do’ſt thou know that, Conſtable?

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: Marry ſir, by my wife, who, if ſhe had bin a wo-
man Cardinally giuen, might haue bin accus’d in forni-
cation, adultery, and all vncleanlineſſe there.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: By the womans meanes?

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: I ſir, by Miſtris Ouer-dons meanes: but as ſhe ſpit
in his face, ſo ſhe deﬁde him.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Sir, if it pleaſe your honor, this is not ſo.

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: Proue it before theſe varlets here, thou honora-
ble man, proue it.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Doe you heare how he miſplaces?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Sir, ſhe came in great with childe: and longing
(ſauing your honors reuerence) for ſtewd prewyns; ſir,
we had but two in the houſe, which at that very diſtant
time ſtood, as it were in a fruit diſh (a diſh of ſome three
pence; your honours haue ſeene ſuch diſhes) they are not
China-diſhes, but very good diſhes.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Go too: go too: no matter for the diſh ſir.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: No indeede ſir not of a pin; you are therein in
the right: but, to the point: As I ſay, this Miſtris Elbow,
being (as I ſay) with childe, and being great bellied, and
longing (as I ſaid) for prewyns: and hauing but two in
the diſh (as I ſaid) Maſter Froth here, this very man, ha-
uing eaten the reſt (as I ſaid) & (as I ſay) paying for them
very honeſtly: for, as you know Maſter Froth, I could not
giue you three pence againe.

speech.speaker: Fro.
speech.line: No indeede.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Very well: you being then (if you be remem-
bred) cracking the ſtones of the foreſaid prewyns.

speech.speaker: Fro.
speech.line: I, ſo I did indeede.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Why, very well: I telling you then (if you be
remembred) that ſuch a one, and ſuch a one, were paſt
cure of the thing you wot of, vnleſſe they kept very good
diet, as I told you.

speech.speaker: Fro.
speech.line: All this is true.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Why very well then.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Come: you are a tedious foole: to the purpoſe:
what was done to Elbowes wife, that hee hath cauſe to
complaine of? Come me to what was done to her.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Sir, your honor cannot come to that yet.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: No ſir, nor I meane it not.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Sir, but you ſhall come to it, by your honours
leaue: And I beſeech you, looke into Maſter Froth here
ſir, a man of foure-ſcore pound a yeare; whoſe father
died at Hallowmas: Was’t not at Hallowmas Maſter
Froth?

speech.speaker: Fro.
speech.line: Allhallond-Eue.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Why very well: I hope here be truthes: he Sir,
ſitting (as I ſay) in a lower chaire, Sir, ’twas in the bunch
of Grapes, where indeede you haue a delight to ſit, haue
you not?

speech.speaker: Fro.
speech.line: I haue ſo, becauſe it is an open roome, and good
for winter.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Why very well then: I hope here be truthes.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: This will laſt out a night in Ruſsia
When nights are longeſt there: Ile take my leaue,
And leaue you to the hearing of the cauſe;
Hoping youle ﬁnde good cauſe to whip them all.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: I thinke no leſſe: good morrow to your Lord-
ſhip. Now Sir, come on: What was done to Elbowes
wife, once more?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Once Sir? there was nothing done to her once.

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: I beſeech you Sir, aske him what this man did to
my wife.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I beſeech your honor, aske me.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Well ſir, what did this Gentleman to her?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I beſeech you ſir, looke in this Gentlemans face:
good Maſter Froth looke vpon his honor; ’tis for a good
purpoſe: doth your honor marke his face?

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: I ſir, very well.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Nay, I beſeech you marke it well.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Well, I doe ſo.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Doth your honor ſee any harme in his face?

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Why no.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Ile be ſuppoſd vpon a booke, his face is the worſt
thing about him: good then: if his face be the worſt
thing about him, how could Maſter Froth doe the Con-
ſtables wife any harme? I would know that of your
honour.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: He’s in the right (Conſtable) what ſay you to it?

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: Firſt, and it like you, the houſe is a reſpeƈted
houſe; next, this is a reſpeƈted fellow; and his Miſtris is
a reſpeƈted woman.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: By this hand Sir, his wife is a more reſpeƈted per-
ſon then any of vs all.

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: Varlet, thou lyeſt; thou lyeſt wicked varlet: the
time is yet to come that ſhee was euer reſpeƈted with
man, woman, or childe.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Sir, ſhe was reſpeƈted with him, before he mar-
ried with her.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Which is the wiſer here; Iuſtice or Iniquitie? Is
this true?

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: O thou caytiﬀe: O thou varlet: O thou wick-
ed Hanniball; I reſpeƈted with her, before I was married
to her? If euer I was reſpeƈted with her, or ſhe with me,
let not your worſhip thinke mee the poore Dukes Oﬃ-
cer: proue this, thou wicked Hanniball, or ile haue
mine aƈtion of battry on thee.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: If he tooke you a box o’th’ eare, you might haue
your aƈtion of ſlander too.

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: Marry I thanke your good worſhip for it: what
is’t your Worſhips pleaſure I ſhall doe with this wick-
ed Caitiﬀe?

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Truly Oﬃcer, becauſe he hath ſome oﬀences in
him, that thou wouldſt diſcouer, if thou couldſt, let him
continue in his courſes, till thou knowſt what they are.

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: Marry I thanke your worſhip for it: Thou ſeeſt
thou wicked varlet now, what’s come vpon thee. Thou
art to continue now thou Varlet, thou art to continue.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Where were you borne, friend?

speech.speaker: Froth.
speech.line: Here in Vienna, Sir.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Are you of foureſcore pounds a yeere?

speech.speaker: Froth.
speech.line: Yes, and’t pleaſe you ſir.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: So: what trade are you of, ſir?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: A Tapſter, a poore widdowes Tapſter.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Your Miſtris name?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Miſtris Ouer-don.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Hath ſhe had any more then one husband?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Nine, ſir: Ouer-don by the laſt.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Nine? come hether to me, Maſter Froth; Maſter
Froth, I would not haue you acquainted with Tapſters;
they will draw you Maſter Froth, and you wil hang them:
get you gon, and let me heare no more of you.

speech.speaker: Fro.
speech.line: I thanke your worſhip: for mine owne part, I
neuer come into any roome in a Tap-houſe, but I am
drawne in.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Well: no more of it Maſter Froth: farewell:
Come you hether to me, Mr. Tapſter: what’s your name
Mr. Tapſter?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Pompey.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: What elſe?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Bum, Sir.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Troth, and your bum is the greateſt thing about
you, ſo that in the beaſtlieſt ſence, you are Pompey the
great; Pompey, you are partly a bawd, Pompey; howſo-
euer you colour it in being a Tapſter, are you not? come,
tell me true, it ſhall be the better for you.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Truly ſir, I am a poore fellow that would liue.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: How would you liue Pompey? by being a bawd?
what doe you thinke of the trade Pompey? is it a lawfull
trade?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: If the Law would allow it, ſir.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: But the Law will not allow it Pompey; nor it
ſhall not be allowed in Vienna.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Do’s your Worſhip meane to geld and ſplay all
the youth of the City?

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: No, Pompey.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Truely Sir, in my poore opinion they will too’t
then: if your worſhip will take order for the drabs and
the knaues, you need not to feare the bawds.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: There is pretty orders beginning I can tell you:
It is but heading, and hanging.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: If you head, and hang all that oﬀend that way
but for ten yeare together; you’ll be glad to giue out a
Commiſſion for more heads: if this law hold in Vienna
ten yeare, ile rent the faireſt houſe in it after three pence
a Bay: if you liue to ſee this come to paſſe, ſay Pompey
told you ſo.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Thanke you good Pompey; and in requitall of
your propheſie, harke you: I aduiſe you let me not ﬁnde
you before me againe vpon any complaint whatſoeuer;
no, not for dwelling where you doe: if I doe Pompey, I
ſhall beat you to your Tent, and proue a ſhrewd Cæſar
to you: in plaine dealing Pompey, I ſhall haue you whipt;
ſo for this time, Pompey, fare you well.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I thanke your Worſhip for your good counſell;
but I ſhall follow it as the ﬂeſh and fortune ſhall better
determine. Whip me? no, no, let Carman whip his Iade,
The valiant heart’s not whipt out of his trade.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Come hether to me, Maſter Elbow: come hither
Maſter Conſtable: how long haue you bin in this place
of Conſtable?

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: Seuen yeere, and a halfe ſir.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: I thought by the readineſſe in the oﬃce, you had
continued in it ſome time: you ſay ſeauen yeares toge-
ther.

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: And a halfe ſir.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Alas, it hath beene great paines to you: they do
you wrong to put you ſo oft vpon’t. Are there not men
in your Ward ſuﬃcient to ſerue it?

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: ’Faith ſir, few of any wit in ſuch matters: as they
are choſen, they are glad to chooſe me for them; I do it
for ſome peece of money, and goe through with all.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Looke you bring mee in the names of ſome ſixe
or ſeuen, the moſt ſuﬃcient of your pariſh.

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: To your Worſhips houſe ſir?

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: To my houſe: fare you well: what’s a clocke,
thinke you?

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: Eleuen, Sir.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: I pray you home to dinner with me.

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: I humbly thanke you.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: It grieues me for the death of Claudio
But there’s no remedie:

speech.speaker: Iuſt.
speech.line: Lord Angelo is ſeuere.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: It is but needfull.
Mercy is not it ſelfe, that oft lookes ſo,
Pardon is ſtill the nurſe of ſecond woe:
But yet, poore Claudio; there is no remedie.
Come Sir.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Hee’s hearing of a Cauſe; he will come ſtraight,
I’le tell him of you.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: ’Pray you doe; Ile know
His pleaſure, may be he will relent; alas
He hath but as oﬀended in a dreame,
All Seƈts, all Ages ſmack of this vice, and he
To die for’t?

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Now, what’s the matter Prouoſt?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Is it your will Claudio ſhall die to morrow?

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Did not I tell thee yea? hadſt thou not order?
Why do’ſt thou aske againe?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Leſt I might be too raſh:
Vnder your good correƈtion I haue ſeene
When after execution, Iudgement hath
Repented ore his doome.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Goe to; let that be mine,
Doe you your oﬃce, or giue vp your Place,
And you ſhall well be ſpar’d.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: I craue your Honours pardon:
What ſhall be done Sir, with the groaning Iuliet?
Shee’s very neere her howre.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Diſpoſe of her
To ſome more ﬁtter place; and that with ſpeed.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Here is the ſiſter of the man condemn’d,
Deſires acceſſe to you.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Hath he a Siſter?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: I my good Lord, a very vertuous maid,
And to be ſhortlie of a Siſter-hood,
If not alreadie.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Well: let her be admitted,
See you the Fornicatreſſe be remou’d,
Let her haue needfull, but not lauiſh meanes,
There ſhall be order for’t.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: ’Saue your Honour.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Stay a little while: y’are welcome: what’s your will?

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: I am a wofull Sutor to your Honour,
’Pleaſe but your Honor heare me.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Well: what’s your ſuite.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: There is a vice that moſt I doe abhorre,
And moſt deſire ſhould meet the blow of Iuſtice;
For which I would not plead, but that I muſt,
For which I muſt not plead, but that I am
At warre, twixt will, and will not.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Well: the matter?

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: I haue a brother is condemn’d to die,
I doe beſeech you let it be his fault,
And not my brother.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Heauen giue thee mouing graces.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Condemne the fault, and not the aƈtor of it,
Why euery fault’s condemnd ere it be done:
Mine were the verie Cipher of a Funƈtion
To ﬁne the faults, whoſe ﬁne ſtands in record,
And let goe by the Aƈtor.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Oh iuſt, but ſeuere Law:
I had a brother then; heauen keepe your honour.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Giue’t not ore ſo: to him againe, entreat him,
Kneele downe before him, hang vpon his gowne,
You are too cold: if you ſhould need a pin,
You could not with more tame a tongue deſire it:
To him, I ſay.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Muſt he needs die?

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Maiden, no remedie.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Yes: I doe thinke that you might pardon him,
And neither heauen, nor man grieue at the mercy.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: I will not doe’t.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: But can you if you would?

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Looke what I will not, that I cannot doe.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: But might you doe’t & do the world no wrong
If ſo your heart were touch’d with that remorſe,
As mine is to him?

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Hee’s ſentenc’d, tis too late.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: You are too cold.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Too late? why no: I that doe ſpeak a word
May call it againe: well, beleeue this
No ceremony that to great ones longs,
Not the Kings Crowne; nor the deputed ſword,
The Marſhalls Truncheon, nor the Iudges Robe
Become them with one halfe ſo good a grace
As mercie does: If he had bin as you, and you as he,
You would haue ſlipt like him, but he like you
Would not haue beene ſo ſterne.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Pray you be gone.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: I would to heauen I had your potencie,
And you were Iſabell: ſhould it then be thus?
No: I would tell what ’twere to be a Iudge,
And what a priſoner.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I, touch him: there’s the veine.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Your Brother is a forfeit of the Law,
And you but waſte your words.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Alas, alas:
Why all the ſoules that were, were forfeit once,
And he that might the vantage beſt haue tooke,
Found out the remedie: how would you be,
If he, which is the top of Iudgement, ſhould
But iudge you, as you are? Oh, thinke on that,
And mercie then will breathe within your lips
Like man new made.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Be you content, (faire Maid)
It is the Law, not I, condemne your brother,
Were he my kinſman, brother, or my ſonne,
It ſhould be thus with him: he muſt die to morrow.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: To morrow? oh, that’s ſodaine,
Spare him, ſpare him:
Hee’s not prepar’d for death; euen for our kitchins
We kill the fowle of ſeaſon: ſhall we ſerue heauen
With leſſe reſpeƈt then we doe miniſter
To our groſſe-ſelues? good, good my Lord, bethink you;
Who is it that hath di’d for this oﬀence?
There’s many haue committed it.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I, well ſaid.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: The Law hath not bin dead, thogh it hath ſlept
Thoſe many had not dar’d to doe that euill
If the ﬁrſt, that did th’ Ediƈt infringe
Had anſwer’d for his deed. Now ’tis awake,
Takes note of what is done, and like a Prophet
Lookes in a glaſſe that ſhewes what future euils
Either now, or by remiſſeneſſe, new conceiu’d,
And ſo in progreſſe to be hatch’d, and borne,
Are now to haue no ſucceſſiue degrees,
But here they liue to end.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Yet ſhew ſome pittie.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: I ſhew it moſt of all, when I ſhow Iuſtice;
For then I pittie thoſe I doe not know,
Which a diſmis’d oﬀence, would after gaule
And doe him right, that anſwering one foule wrong
Liues not to aƈt another. Be ſatisﬁed;
Your Brother dies to morrow; be content.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: So you muſt be ý ﬁrſt that giues this ſentence,
And hee, that ſuﬀers: Oh, it is excellent
To haue a Giants ſtrength: but it is tyrannous
To vſe it like a Giant.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: That’s well ſaid.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Could great men thunder
As Ioue himſelfe do’s, Ioue would neuer be quiet,
For euery pelting petty Oﬃcer
Would vſe his heauen for thunder;
Nothing but thunder: Mercifull heauen,
Thou rather with thy ſharpe and ſulpherous bolt
Splits the vn-wedgable and gnarled Oke,
Then the ſoft Mertill: But man, proud man,
Dreſt in a little briefe authoritie,
Moſt ignorant of what he’s moſt aſſur’d,
(His glaſsie Eſſence) like an angry Ape
Plaies ſuch phantaſtique tricks before high heauen,
As makes the Angels weepe: who with our ſpleenes,
Would all themſelues laugh mortall.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Oh, to him, to him wench: he will relent,
Hee’s comming: I perceiue’t.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Pray heauen ſhe win him.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: We cannot weigh our brother with our ſelfe,
Great men may ieſt with Saints: tis wit in them,
But in the leſſe fowle prophanation.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Thou’rt i’th right (Girle) more o’that.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: That in the Captaine’s but a chollericke word,
Which in the Souldier is ﬂat blaſphemie.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Art auis’d o’that? more on’t.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Why doe you put theſe ſayings vpon me?

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Becauſe Authoritie, though it erre like others,
Hath yet a kinde of medicine in it ſelfe
That skins the vice o’th top; goe to your boſome,
Knock there, and aske your heart what it doth know
That’s like my brothers fault: if it confeſſe
A naturall guiltineſſe, ſuch as is his,
Let it not ſound a thought vpon your tongue
Againſt my brothers life.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Shee ſpeakes, and ’tis ſuch ſence
That my Sence breeds with it; fare you well.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Gentle my Lord, turne backe.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: I will bethinke me: come againe to morrow.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Hark, how Ile bribe you: good my Lord turn back.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: How? bribe me?

speech.speaker: Is.
speech.line: I, with ſuch gifts that heauen ſhall ſhare with you.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: You had mar’d all elſe.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Not with fond Sickles of the teſted-gold,
Or Stones, whoſe rate are either rich, or poore
As fancie values them: but with true prayers,
That ſhall be vp at heauen, and enter there
Ere Sunne riſe: prayers from preſerued ſoules,
From faſting Maides, whoſe mindes are dedicate
To nothing temporall.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Well: come to me to morrow.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Goe to: ’tis well; away.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Heauen keepe your honour ſafe.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Amen.
For I am that way going to temptation,
Where prayers croſſe.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: At what hower to morrow,
Shall I attend your Lordſhip?

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: At any time ’fore-noone.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: ’Saue your Honour.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: From thee: euen from thy vertue.
What’s this? what’s this? is this her fault, or mine?
The Tempter, or the Tempted, who ſins moſt? ha?
Not ſhe: nor doth ſhe tempt: but it is I,
That, lying by the Violet in the Sunne,
Doe as the Carrion do’s, not as the ﬂowre,
Corrupt with vertuous ſeaſon: Can it be,
That Modeſty may more betray our Sence
Then womans lightneſſe? hauing waſte ground enough,
Shall we deſire to raze the Sanƈtuary
And pitch our euils there? oh ﬁe, ﬁe, ﬁe:
What doſt thou? or what art thou Angelo?
Doſt thou deſire her fowly, for thoſe things
That make her good? oh, let her brother liue:
Theeues for their robbery haue authority,
When Iudges ſteale themſelues: what, doe I loue her,
That I deſire to heare her ſpeake againe?
And feaſt vpon her eyes? what is’t I dreame on?
Oh cunning enemy, that to catch a Saint,
With Saints doſt bait thy hooke: moſt dangerous
Is that temptation, that doth goad vs on
To ſinne, in louing vertue: neuer could the Strumpet
With all her double vigor, Art, and Nature
Once ſtir my temper: but this vertuous Maid
Subdues me quite: Euer till now
When men were fond, I ſmild, and wondred how.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Haile to you, Prouoſt, ſo I thinke you are.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: I am the Prouoſt: whats your will, good Frier?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Bound by my charity, and my bleſt order,
I come to viſite the afﬂiƈted ſpirits
Here in the priſon: doe me the common right
To let me ſee them: and to make me know
The nature of their crimes, that I may miniſter
To them accordingly.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: I would do more then that, if more were needfull
Looke here comes one: a Gentlewoman of mine,
Who falling in the ﬂawes of her owne youth,
Hath bliſterd her report: She is with childe,
And he that got it, ſentenc’d: a yong man,
More ﬁt to doe another ſuch oﬀence,
Then dye for this.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: When muſt he dye?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: As I do thinke to morrow.
I haue prouided for you, ſtay a while
And you ſhall be conduƈted.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Repent you (faire one) of the ſin you carry?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: I doe; and beare the ſhame moſt patiently.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: Ile teach you how you ſhal araign your conſciēce
And try your penitence, if it be ſound,
Or hollowly put on.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Ile gladly learne.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Loue you the man that wrong’d you?

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Yes, as I loue the woman that wrong’d him.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: So then it ſeemes your moſt oﬀence full aƈt
Was mutually committed.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Mutually.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Then was your ſin of heauier kinde then his.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: I doe confeſſe it, and repent it (Father.)

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: ’Tis meet ſo (daughter) but leaſt you do repent
As that the ſin hath brought you to this ſhame,
Which ſorrow is alwaies toward our ſelues, not heauen,
Showing we would not ſpare heauen, as we loue it,
But as we ſtand in feare.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: I doe repent me, as it is an euill,
And take the ſhame with ioy.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: There reſt:
Your partner (as I heare) muſt die to morrow,
And I am going with inſtruƈtion to him:
Grace goe with you, Benedicite.

speech.speaker: Iul.
speech.line: Muſt die to morrow? oh iniurious Loue
That reſpits me a life, whoſe very comfort
Is ſtill a dying horror.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: ’Tis pitty of him.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: When I would pray, & think, I thinke, and pray
To ſeuerall ſubieƈts: heauen hath my empty words,
Whilſt my Inuention, hearing not my Tongue,
Anchors on Iſabell: heauen in my mouth,
As if I did but onely chew his name,
And in my heart the ſtrong and ſwelling euill
Of my conception: the ſtate whereon I ſtudied
Is like a good thing, being often read
Growne feard, and tedious: yea, my Grauitie
Wherein (let no man heare me) I take pride,
Could I, with boote, change for an idle plume
Which the ayre beats for vaine: oh place, oh forme,
How often doſt thou with thy caſe, thy habit
Wrench awe from fooles, and tye the wiſer ſoules
To thy falſe ſeeming? Blood, thou art blood,
Let’s write good Angell on the Deuills horne
’Tis not the Deuills Creſt: how now? who’s there?

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: One Iſabell, a Siſter, deſires acceſſe to you.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Teach her the way: oh, heauens
Why doe’s my bloud thus muſter to my heart,
Making both it vnable for it ſelfe,
And diſpoſſeſsing all my other parts
Of neceſſary ﬁtneſſe?
So play the fooliſh throngs with one that ſwounds,
Come all to help him, and ſo ſtop the ayre
By which hee ſhould reuiue: and euen ſo
The generall ſubieƈt to a wel-wiſht King
Quit their owne part, and in obſequious fondneſſe
Crowd to his preſence, where their vn-taught loue
Muſt needs appear oﬀence: how now faire Maid.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: I am come to know your pleaſure.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: That you might know it, wold much better pleaſe me,
Then to demand what ’tis: your Brother cannot liue.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Euen ſo: heauen keepe your Honor.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Yet may he liue a while: and it may be
As long as you, or I: yet he muſt die.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Vnder your Sentence?

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Yea.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: When, I beſeech you: that in his Reprieue
(Longer, or ſhorter) he may be ſo ﬁtted
That his ſoule ſicken not.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Ha? ﬁe, theſe ﬁlthy vices: It were as good
To pardon him, that hath from nature ſtolne
A man already made, as to remit
Their ſawcie ſweetnes, that do coyne heauens Image
In ſtamps that are forbid: ’tis all as eaſie,
Falſely to take away a life true made,
As to put mettle in reſtrained meanes
To make a falſe one.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: ’Tis ſet downe ſo in heauen, but not in earth.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Say you ſo: then I ſhall poze you quickly.
Which had you rather, that the moſt iuſt Law
Now tooke your brothers life, and to redeeme him
Giue vp your body to ſuch ſweet vncleanneſſe
As ſhe that he hath ſtaind?

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Sir, beleeue this.
I had rather giue my body, then my ſoule.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: I talke not of your ſoule: our compel’d ſins
Stand more for number, then for accompt.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: How ſay you?

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Nay Ile not warrant that: for I can ſpeake
Againſt the thing I ſay: Anſwere to this,
I (now the voyce of the recorded Law)
Pronounce a ſentence on your Brothers life,
Might there not be a charitie in ſinne,
To ſaue this Brothers life?

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Pleaſe you to doo’t,
Ile take it as a perill to my ſoule,
It is no ſinne at all, but charitie.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Pleaſ’d you to doo’t, at perill of your ſoule
Were equall poize of ſinne, and charitie.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: That I do beg his life, if it be ſinne
Heauen let me beare it: you granting of my ſuit,
If that be ſin, Ile make it my Morne-praier,
To haue it added to the faults of mine,
And nothing of your anſwere.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Nay, but heare me,
Your ſence purſues not mine: either you are ignorant,
Or ſeeme ſo crafty; and that’s not good.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Let be ignorant, and in nothing good,
But graciouſly to know I am no better.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Thus wiſdome wiſhes to appeare moſt bright,
When it doth taxe it ſelfe: As theſe blacke Maſques
Proclaime an en-ſhield beauty ten times louder
Then beauty could diſplaied: But marke me,
To be receiued plaine, Ile ſpeake more groſſe:
Your Brother is to dye.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: So.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: And his oﬀence is ſo, as it appeares,
Accountant to the Law, vpon that paine.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: True.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Admit no other way to ſaue his life
(As I ſubſcribe not that, nor any other,
But in the loſſe of queſtion) that you, his Siſter,
Finding your ſelfe deſir’d of ſuch a perſon,
Whoſe creadit with the Iudge, or owne great place,
Could fetch your Brother from the Manacles
Of the all-building-Law: and that there were
No earthly meane to ſaue him, but that either
You muſt lay downe the treaſures of your body,
To this ſuppoſed, or elſe to let him ſuﬀer:
What would you doe?

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: As much for my poore Brother, as my ſelfe;
That is: were I vnder the tearmes of death,
Th’ impreſſion of keene whips, I’ld weare as Rubies,
And ſtrip my ſelfe to death, as to a bed,
That longing haue bin ſicke for, ere I’ld yeeld
My body vp to ſhame.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Then muſt your brother die.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: And ’twer the cheaper way:
Better it were a brother dide at once,
Then that a ſiſter, by redeeming him
Should die for euer.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Were not you then as cruell as the Sentence,
That you haue ſlander’d ſo?

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Ignomie in ranſome, and free pardon
Are of two houſes: lawfull mercie,
Is nothing kin to fowle redemption.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: You ſeem’d of late to make the Law a tirant,
And rather prou’d the ſliding of your brother
A merriment, then a vice.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Oh pardon me my Lord, it oft fals out
To haue, what we would haue,
We ſpeake not what vve meane;
I ſomething do excuſe the thing I hate,
For his aduantage that I dearely loue.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: We are all fraile.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Elſe let my brother die,
If not a fedarie but onely he
Owe, and ſucceed thy weakneſſe.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Nay, women are fraile too.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: I, as the glaſſes where they view themſelues,
Which are as eaſie broke as they make formes:
Women? Helpe heauen; men their creation marre
In proﬁting by them: Nay, call vs ten times fraile,
For we are ſoft, as our complexions are,
And credulous to falſe prints.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: I thinke it well:
And from this teſtimonie of your owne ſex
(Since I ſuppoſe we are made to be no ſtronger
Then faults may ſhake our frames) let me be bold;
I do arreſt your words. Be that you are,
That is a woman; if you be more, you’r none.
If you be one (as you are well expreſt
By all externall warrants) ſhew it now,
By putting on the deſtin’d Liuerie.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: I haue no tongue but one; gentle my Lord,
Let me entreate you ſpeake the former language.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Plainlie conceiue I loue you.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: My brother did loue Iuliet,
And you tell me that he ſhall die for’t.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: He ſhall not Iſabell if you giue me loue.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: I know your vertue hath a licence in’t,
Which ſeemes a little fouler then it is,
To plucke on others.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Beleeue me on mine Honor,
My words expreſſe my purpoſe.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Ha? Little honor, to be much beleeu’d,
And moſt pernitious purpoſe: Seeming, ſeeming.
I will proclaime thee Angelo, looke for’t.
Signe me a preſent pardon for my brother,
Or with an out-ſtretcht throate Ile tell the world aloud
What man thou art.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Who will beleeue thee Iſabell?
My vnſoild name, th’ auſteereneſſe of my life,
My vouch againſt you, and my place i’th State,
Will ſo your accuſation ouer-weigh,
That you ſhall ſtiﬂe in your owne report,
And ſmell of calumnie. I haue begun,
And now I giue my ſenſuall race, the reine,
Fit thy conſent to my ſharpe appetite,
Lay by all nicetie, and prolixious bluſhes
That baniſh what they ſue for: Redeeme thy brother,
By yeelding vp thy bodie to my will,
Or elſe he muſt not onelie die the death,
But thy vnkindneſſe ſhall his death draw out
To lingring ſuﬀerance: Anſwer me to morrow,
Or by the aﬀeƈtion that now guides me moſt,
Ile proue a Tirant to him. As for you,
Say what you can; my falſe, ore-weighs your true.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: To whom ſhould I complaine? Did I tell this,
Who would beleeue me? O perilous mouthes
That beare in them, one and the ſelfeſame tongue,
Either of condemnation, or approofe,
Bidding the Law make curtſie to their will,
Hooking both right and wrong to th’ appetite,
To follow as it drawes. Ile to my brother,
Though he hath falne by prompture of the blood,
Yet hath he in him ſuch a minde of Honor,
That had he twentie heads to tender downe
On twentie bloodie blockes, hee’ld yeeld them vp,
Before his ſiſter ſhould her bodie ſtoope
To ſuch abhord pollution.
Then Iſabell liue chaſte, and brother die;
“More then our Brother, is our Chaſtitie.
Ile tell him yet of Angelo’s requeſt,
And ﬁt his minde to death, for his ſoules reſt.

speech.speaker: Du.
speech.line: So then you hope of pardon from Lord Angelo?

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: The miſerable haue no other medicine
But onely hope: I’haue hope to liue, and am prepar’d to
die.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Be abſolute for death: either death or life
Shall thereby be the ſweeter. Reaſon thus with life:
If I do looſe thee, I do looſe a thing
That none but fooles would keepe: a breath thou art,
Seruile to all the skyie-inﬂuences
That doſt this habitation where thou keepſt
Hourely afﬂiƈt: Meerely, thou art deaths foole,
For him thou labourſt by thy ﬂight to ſhun,
And yet runſt toward him ſtill. Thou art not noble,
For all th’ accommodations that thou bearſt,
Are nurſt by baſeneſſe: Thou’rt by no meanes valiant,
For thou doſt feare the ſoft and tender forke
Of a poore worme: thy beſt of reſt is ſleepe,
And that thou oft prouoakſt, yet groſſelie fearſt
Thy death, which is no more. Thou art not thy ſelfe,
For thou exiſts on manie a thouſand graines
That iſſue out of duſt. Happie thou art not,
For what thou haſt not, ſtill thou ſtriu’ſt to get,
And what thou haſt forgetſt. Thou art not certaine,
For thy complexion ſhifts to ſtrange eﬀeƈts,
After the Moone: If thou art rich, thou’rt poore,
For like an Aſſe, whoſe backe with Ingots bowes;
Thou bearſt thy heauie riches but a iournie,
And death vnloads thee; Friend haſt thou none.
For thine owne bowels which do call thee, ﬁre
The meere eﬀuſion of thy proper loines
Do curſe the Gowt, Sapego, and the Rheume
For ending thee no ſooner. Thou haſt nor youth, nor age
But as it were an after-dinners ſleepe
Dreaming on both, for all thy bleſſed youth
Becomes as aged, and doth begge the almes
Of palſied-Eld: and when thou art old, and rich
Thou haſt neither heate, aﬀeƈtion, limbe, nor beautie
To make thy riches pleaſant: what’s yet in this
That beares the name of life? Yet in this life
Lie hid moe thouſand deaths; yet death we feare
That makes theſe oddes, all euen.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: I humblie thanke you.
To ſue to liue, I ﬁnde I ſeeke to die,
And ſeeking death, ﬁnde life: Let it come on.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: What hoa? Peace heere; Grace, and good com-
panie.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Who’s there? Come in, the wiſh deſerues a
welcome.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Deere ſir, ere long Ile viſit you againe.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Moſt holie Sir, I thanke you.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: My buſineſſe is a word or two with Claudio.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: And verie welcom: looke Signior, here’s your
ſiſter.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Prouoſt, a word with you.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: As manie as you pleaſe.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Bring them to heare me ſpeak, where I may be
conceal’d.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Now ſiſter, what’s the comfort?

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Why,
As all comforts are: moſt good, moſt good indeede,
Lord Angelo hauing aﬀaires to heauen
Intends you for his ſwift Ambaſſador,
Where you ſhall be an euerlaſting Leiger;
Therefore your beſt appointment make with ſpeed,
To Morrow you ſet on.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Is there no remedie?

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: None, but ſuch remedie, as to ſaue a head
To cleaue a heart in twaine:

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: But is there anie?

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Yes brother, you may liue;
There is a diuelliſh mercie in the Iudge,
If you’l implore it, that will free your life,
But fetter you till death.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Perpetuall durance?

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: I iuſt, perpetuall durance, a reſtraint
Through all the worlds vaſtiditie you had
To a determin’d ſcope.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: But in what nature?

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: In ſuch a one, as you conſenting too’t,
Would barke your honor from that trunke you beare,
And leaue you naked.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Let me know the point.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Oh, I do feare thee Claudio, and I quake,
Leaſt thou a feauorous life ſhouldſt entertaine,
And ſix or ſeuen winters more reſpeƈt
Then a perpetuall Honor. Dar’ſt thou die?
The ſence of death is moſt in apprehenſion,
And the poore Beetle that we treade vpon
In corporall ſuﬀerance, ﬁnds a pang as great,
As when a Giant dies.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Why giue you me this ſhame?
Thinke you I can a reſolution fetch
From ﬂowrie tenderneſſe? If I muſt die,
I will encounter darkneſſe as a bride,
And hugge it in mine armes.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: There ſpake my brother: there my fathers graue
Did vtter forth a voice. Yes, thou muſt die:
Thou art too noble, to conſerue a life
In baſe appliances. This outward ſainted Deputie,
Whoſe ſetled viſage, and deliberate word
Nips youth i’th head, and follies doth emmew
As Falcon doth the Fowle, is yet a diuell:
His ﬁlth within being caſt, he would appeare
A pond, as deepe as hell.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: The prenzie, Angelo?

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Oh ’tis the cunning Liuerie of hell,
The damneſt bodie to inueſt, and couer
In prenzie gardes; doſt thou thinke Claudio,
If I would yeeld him my virginitie
Thou might’ſt be freed?

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Oh heauens, it cannot be.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Yes, he would giu’t thee; from this rank oﬀence
So to oﬀend him ſtill. This night’s the time
That I ſhould do what I abhorre to name,
Or elſe thou dieſt to morrow.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Thou ſhalt not do’t.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: O, were it but my life,
I’de throw it downe for your deliuerance
As frankely as a pin.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Thankes deere Iſabell.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Be readie Claudio, for your death to morrow.

speech.speaker: Clau.
speech.line: Yes. Has he aﬀeƈtions in him,
That thus can make him bite the Law by th’ noſe,
When he would force it? Sure it is no ſinne,
Or of the deadly ſeuen it is the leaſt.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Which is the leaſt?

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: If it were damnable, he being ſo wiſe,
Why would he for the momentarie tricke
Be perdurablie ﬁn’de? Oh Iſabell.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: What ſaies my brother?

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Death is a fearefull thing.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: And ſhamed life, a hatefull.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: I, but to die, and go we know not where,
To lie in cold obſtruƈtion, and to rot,
This ſenſible warme motion, to become
A kneaded clod; And the delighted ſpirit
To bath in ﬁerie ﬂoods, or to recide
In thrilling Region of thicke-ribbed Ice,
To be impriſon’d in the viewleſſe windes
And blowne with reſtleſſe violence round about
The pendant world: or to be worſe then worſt
Of thoſe, that lawleſſe and incertaine thought,
Imagine howling, ’tis too horrible.
The wearieſt, and moſt loathed worldly life
That Age, Ache, periury, and impriſonment
Can lay on nature, is a Paradiſe
To what we feare of death.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Alas, alas.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Sweet Siſter, let me liue.
What ſinne you do, to ſaue a brothers life,
Nature diſpenſes with the deede ſo farre,
That it becomes a vertue.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Oh you beaſt,
Oh faithleſſe Coward, oh diſhoneſt wretch,
Wilt thou be made a man, out of my vice?
Is’t not a kinde of Inceſt, to take life
From thine owne ſiſters ſhame? What ſhould I thinke,
Heauen ſhield my Mother plaid my Father faire:
For ſuch a warped ſlip of wilderneſſe
Nere iſſu’d from his blood. Take my deﬁance,
Die, periſh: Might but my bending downe
Repreeue thee from thy fate, it ſhould proceede.
Ile pray a thouſand praiers for thy death,
No word to ſaue thee.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Nay heare me Iſabell.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Oh ﬁe, ﬁe, ﬁe:
Thy ſinn’s not accidentall, but a Trade;
Mercy to thee would proue it ſelfe a Bawd,
’Tis beſt that thou dieſt quickly.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Oh heare me Iſabella.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Vouchſafe a word, yong ſiſter, but one word.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: What is your Will.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Might you diſpenſe with your leyſure, I would
by and by haue ſome ſpeech with you: the ſatiſfaƈtion I
would require, is likewiſe your owne beneﬁt.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: I haue no ſuperﬂuous leyſure, my ſtay muſt be
ſtolen out of other aﬀaires: but I will attend you a while.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Son, I haue ouer-heard what hath paſt between
you & your ſiſter. Angelo had neuer the purpoſe to cor-
rupt her; onely he hath made an aſſay of her vertue, to
praƈtiſe his iudgement with the diſpoſition of natures.
She (hauing the truth of honour in her) hath made him
that gracious deniall, which he is moſt glad to receiue: I
am Confeſſor to Angelo, and I know this to be true, ther-
fore prepare your ſelfe to death: do not ſatisﬁe your re-
ſolution with hopes that are fallible, to morrow you
muſt die, goe to your knees, and make ready.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Let me ask my ſiſter pardon, I am ſo out of loue
with life, that I will ſue to be rid of it.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Hold you there: farewell: Prouoſt, a word
with you.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: What’s your will (father?)

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: That now you are come, you wil be gone: leaue
me a while with the Maid, my minde promiſes with my
habit, no loſſe ſhall touch her by my company.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: In good time.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: The hand that hath made you faire, hath made
you good: the goodnes that is cheape in beauty, makes
beauty briefe in goodnes; but grace being the ſoule of
your complexion, ſhall keepe the body of it euer faire:
the aſſault that Angelo hath made to you, Fortune hath
conuaid to my vnderſtanding; and but that frailty hath
examples for his falling, I ſhould wonder at Angelo: how
will you doe to content this Subſtitute, and to ſaue your
Brother?

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: I am now going to reſolue him: I had rather
my brother die by the Law, then my ſonne ſhould be vn-
lawfullie borne. But (oh) how much is the good Duke
deceiu’d in Angelo: if euer he returne, and I can ſpeake
to him, I will open my lips in vaine, or diſcouer his go-
uernment.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: That ſhall not be much amiſſe: yet, as the mat-
ter now ſtands, he will auoid your accuſation: he made
triall of you onelie. Therefore faſten your eare on my
aduiſings, to the loue I haue in doing good; a remedie
preſents it ſelfe. I doe make my ſelfe beleeue that you
may moſt vprighteouſly do a poor wronged Lady a me-
rited beneﬁt; redeem your brother from the angry Law;
doe no ſtaine to your owne gracious perſon, and much
pleaſe the abſent Duke, if peraduenture he ſhall euer re-
turne to haue hearing of this buſineſſe.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Let me heare you ſpeake farther; I haue ſpirit to
do any thing that appeares not fowle in the truth of my
ſpirit.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Vertue is bold, and goodnes neuer fearefull:
Haue you not heard ſpeake of Mariana the ſiſter of Fre-
dericke the great Souldier, who miſcarried at Sea?

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: I haue heard of the Lady, and good words went
with her name.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Shee ſhould this Angelo haue married: was af-
ﬁanced to her oath, and the nuptiall appointed: between
which time of the contraƈt, and limit of the ſolemnitie,
her brother Fredericke was wrackt at Sea, hauing in that
periſhed veſſell, the dowry of his ſiſter: but marke how
heauily this befell to the poore Gentlewoman, there ſhe
loſt a noble and renowned brother, in his loue toward
her, euer moſt kinde and naturall: with him the portion
and ſinew of her fortune, her marriage dowry: with
both, her combynate-husband, this well-ſeeming
Angelo.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Can this be ſo? did Angelo ſo leaue her?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Left her in her teares, & dried not one of them
with his comfort: ſwallowed his vowes whole, preten-
ding in her, diſcoueries of diſhonor: in few, beſtow’d
her on her owne lamentation, which ſhe yet weares for
his ſake: and he, a marble to her teares, is waſhed with
them, but relents not.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: What a merit were it in death to take this poore
maid from the world? what corruption in this life, that
it will let this man liue? But how out of this can ſhee a-
uaile?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: It is a rupture that you may eaſily heale: and the
cure of it not onely ſaues your brother, but keepes you
from diſhonor in doing it.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Shew me how (good Father.)

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: This fore-named Maid hath yet in her the con-
tinuance of her ﬁrſt aﬀeƈtion: his vniuſt vnkindeneſſe
(that in all reaſon ſhould haue quenched her loue) hath
(like an impediment in the Current) made it more vio-
lent and vnruly: Goe you to Angelo, anſwere his requi-
ring with a plauſible obedience, agree with his demands
to the point: onely referre your ſelfe to this aduantage;
ﬁrſt, that your ſtay with him may not be long: that the
time may haue all ſhadow, and ſilence in it: and the place
anſwere to conuenience: this being granted in courſe,
and now followes all: wee ſhall aduiſe this wronged
maid to ſteed vp your appointment, goe in your place:
if the encounter acknowledge it ſelfe heereafter, it may
compell him to her recompence; and heere, by this is
your brother ſaued, your honor vntainted, the poore
Mariana aduantaged, and the corrupt Deputy ſcaled.
The Maid will I frame, and make ﬁt for his attempt: if
you thinke well to carry this as you may, the doublenes
of the beneﬁt defends the deceit from reproofe. What
thinke you of it?

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: The image of it giues me content already, and I
truſt it will grow to a moſt proſperous perfeƈtion.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: It lies much in your holding vp: haſte you ſpee-
dily to Angelo, if for this night he intreat you to his bed,
giue him promiſe of ſatisfaƈtion: I will preſently to S.
Lukes, there at the moated-Grange recides this deie-
ƈted Mariana; at that place call vpon me, and diſpatch
with Angelo, that it may be quickly.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: I thank you for this comfort: fare you well good
father.

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: Nay, if there be no remedy for it, but that you
will needes buy and ſell men and women like beaſts, we
ſhall haue all the world drinke browne & white baſtard.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Oh heauens, what ſtuﬀe is heere.

speech.speaker: Clow.
speech.line: Twas neuer merry world ſince of two vſuries
the merrieſt was put downe, and the worſer allow’d by
order of Law; a fur’d gowne to keepe him warme; and
furd with Foxe and Lamb-skins too, to ſigniﬁe, that craft
being richer then Innocency, ſtands for the facing.

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: Come your way ſir: ’bleſſe you good Father
Frier.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: And you good Brother Father; what oﬀence
hath this man made you, Sir?

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: Marry Sir, he hath oﬀended the Law; and Sir,
we take him to be a Theefe too Sir: for wee haue found
vpon him Sir, a ſtrange Pick-lock, which we haue ſent
to the Deputie.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Fie, ſirrah, a Bawd, a wicked bawd,
The euill that thou cauſeſt to be done,
That is thy meanes to liue. Do thou but thinke
What ’tis to cram a maw, or cloath a backe
From ſuch a ﬁlthie vice: ſay to thy ſelfe,
From their abhominable and beaſtly touches
I drinke, I eate away my ſelfe, and liue:
Canſt thou beleeue thy liuing is a life,
So ſtinkingly depending? Go mend, go mend.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Indeed, it do’s ſtinke in ſome ſort, Sir:
But yet Sir I would proue.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Nay, if the diuell haue giuen thee proofs for ſin
Thou wilt proue his. Take him to priſon Oﬃcer:
Correƈtion, and Inſtruƈtion muſt both worke
Ere this rude beaſt will proﬁt.

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: He muſt before the Deputy Sir, he ha’s giuen
him warning: the Deputy cannot abide a Whore-ma-
ſter: if he be a Whore-monger, and comes before him,
he were as good go a mile on his errand.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: That we were all, as ſome would ſeeme to bee
From our faults, as faults from ſeeming free.

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: His necke will come to your waſt, a Cord ſir.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I ſpy comfort, I cry baile: Here’s a Gentleman,
and a friend of mine.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: How now noble Pompey? What, at the wheels
of Cæſar? Art thou led in triumph? What is there none
of Pigmalions Images newly made woman to bee had
now, for putting the hand in the pocket, and extraƈting
clutch’d? What reply? Ha? What ſaiſt thou to this
Tune, Matter, and Method? Is’t not drown’d i’th laſt
raine? Ha? What ſaiſt thou Trot? Is the world as it was
Man? Which is the vvay? Is it ſad, and few words?
Or how? The tricke of it?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Still thus, and thus: ſtill vvorſe?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: How doth my deere Morſell, thy Miſtris? Pro-
cures ſhe ſtill? Ha?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Troth ſir, ſhee hath eaten vp all her beefe, and
ſhe is her ſelfe in the tub.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Why ’tis good: It is the right of it: it muſt be
ſo. Euer your freſh Whore, and your pouder’d Baud, an
vnſhun’d conſequence, it muſt be ſo. Art going to pri-
ſon Pompey?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Yes faith ſir.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Why ’tis not amiſſe Pompey: farewell: goe ſay
I ſent thee thether: for debt Pompey? Or how?

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: For being a baud, for being a baud.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Well, then impriſon him: If impriſonment be
the due of a baud, why ’tis his right. Baud is he doubt-
leſſe, and of antiquity too: Baud borne. Farwell good
Pompey: Commend me to the priſon Pompey, you will
turne good husband now Pompey, you vvill keepe the
houſe.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I hope Sir, your good Worſhip wil be my baile?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: No indeed vvil I not Pompey, it is not the wear:
I will pray (Pompey) to encreaſe your bondage if you
take it not patiently: Why, your mettle is the more:
Adieu truſtie Pompey.
Bleſſe you Friar.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: And you.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Do’s Bridget paint ſtill, Pompey? Ha?

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: Come your waies ſir, come.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: You will not baile me then Sir?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Then Pompey, nor now: what newes abroad Fri-
er? What newes?

speech.speaker: Elb.
speech.line: Come your waies ſir, come.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Goe to kennell (Pompey) goe:
What newes Frier of the Duke?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: I know none: can you tell me of any?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Some ſay he is with the Emperor of Ruſſia: other
ſome, he is in Rome: but where is he thinke you?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: I know not where: but whereſoeuer, I wiſh
him well.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: It was a mad fantaſticall tricke of him to ſteale
from the State, and vſurpe the beggerie hee was neuer
borne to: Lord Angelo Dukes it well in his abſence: he
puts tranſgreſſion too’t.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: He do’s well in’t.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: A little more lenitie to Lecherie would doe no
harme in him: Something too crabbed that way, Frier.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: It is too general a vice, and ſeueritie muſt cure it.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Yes in good ſooth, the vice is of a great kindred;
it is vvell allied, but it is impoſſible to extirpe it quite,
Frier, till eating and drinking be put downe. They ſay
this Angelo vvas not made by Man and Woman, after
this downe-right vvay of Creation: is it true, thinke
you?

speech.speaker: Duke.
