speech.line: How ſhould he be made then?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Some report, a Sea-maid ſpawn’d him. Some,
that he vvas begot betweene two Stock-ﬁſhes. But it
is certaine, that when he makes water, his Vrine is con-
geal’d ice, that I know to bee true: and he is a motion
generatiue, that’s infallible.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: You are pleaſant ſir, and ſpeake apace.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Why, what a ruthleſſe thing is this in him, for
the rebellion of a Cod-peece, to take away the life of a
man? Would the Duke that is abſent haue done this?
Ere he vvould haue hang’d a man for the getting a hun-
dred Baſtards, he vvould haue paide for the Nurſing a
thouſand. He had ſome feeling of the ſport, hee knew
the ſeruice, and that inſtruƈted him to mercie.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: I neuer heard the abſent Duke much deteƈted
for Women, he was not enclin’d that vvay.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Oh Sir, you are deceiu’d.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: ’Tis not poſſible.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Who, not the Duke? Yes, your beggar of ﬁfty:
and his vſe was, to put a ducket in her Clack-diſh; the
Duke had Crochets in him. Hee would be drunke too,
that let me informe you.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: You do him wrong, ſurely.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Sir, I vvas an inward of his: a ſhie fellow vvas
the Duke, and I beleeue I know the cauſe of his vvith-
drawing.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: What (I prethee) might be the cauſe?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: No, pardon: ’Tis a ſecret muſt bee lockt with-
in the teeth and the lippes: but this I can let you vnder-
ſtand, the greater ﬁle of the ſubieƈt held the Duke to be
vviſe.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Wiſe? Why no queſtion but he was.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: A very ſuperﬁciall, ignorant, vnweighing fellow

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Either this is Enuie in you, Folly, or miſta-
king: The very ſtreame of his life, and the buſineſſe he
hath helmed, muſt vppon a warranted neede, giue him
a better proclamation. Let him be but teſtimonied in
his owne bringings forth, and hee ſhall appeare to the
enuious, a Scholler, a Stateſman, and a Soldier: there-
fore you ſpeake vnskilfully: or, if your knowledge bee
more, it is much darkned in your malice.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Sir, I know him, and I loue him.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Loue talkes with better knowledge, & know-
ledge with deare loue.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Come Sir, I know what I know.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: I can hardly beleeue that, ſince you know not
what you ſpeake. But if euer the Duke returne (as our
praiers are he may) let mee deſire you to make your an-
ſwer before him: if it bee honeſt you haue ſpoke, you
haue courage to maintaine it; I am bound to call vppon
you, and I pray you your name?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Sir my name is Lucio, wel known to the Duke.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: He ſhall know you better Sir, if I may liue to
report you.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I feare you not.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: O, you hope the Duke will returne no more:
or you imagine me to vnhurtfull an oppoſite: but indeed
I can doe you little harme: You’ll for-ſweare this a-
gaine?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Ile be hang’d ﬁrſt: Thou art deceiu’d in mee
Friar. But no more of this: Canſt thou tell if Claudio
die to morrow, or no?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Why ſhould he die Sir?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Why? For ﬁlling a bottle with a Tunne-diſh:
I would the Duke we talke of were return’d againe: this
vngenitur’d Agent will vn-people the Prouince with
Continencie. Sparrowes muſt not build in his houſe-
eeues, becauſe they are lecherous: The Duke yet would
haue darke deeds darkelie anſwered, hee would neuer
bring them to light: would hee were return’d. Marrie
this Claudio is condemned for vntruſſing. Farwell good
Friar, I prethee pray for me: The Duke (I ſay to thee
againe) would eate Mutton on Fridaies. He’s now paſt
it, yet (and I ſay to thee) hee would mouth with a beg-
gar, though ſhe ſmelt browne-bread and Garlicke: ſay
that I ſaid ſo: Farewell.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: No might, nor greatneſſe in mortality
Can cenſure ſcape: Back-wounding calumnie
The whiteſt vertue ſtrikes. What King ſo ſtrong,
Can tie the gall vp in the ſlanderous tong?
But who comes heere?

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Go, away with her to priſon.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: Good my Lord be good to mee, your Honor
is accounted a mercifull man: good my Lord.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Double, and trebble admonition, and ſtill for-
feite in the ſame kinde? This would make mercy ſweare
and play the Tirant.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: A Bawd of eleuen yeares continuance, may it
pleaſe your Honor.

speech.speaker: Bawd.
speech.line: My Lord, this is one Lucio’s information a-
gainſt me, Miſtris Kate Keepe-downe was with childe by
him in the Dukes time, he promis’d her marriage: his
Childe is a yeere and a quarter olde come Philip and Ia-
cob: I haue kept it my ſelfe; and ſee how hee goes about
to abuſe me.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: That fellow is a fellow of much Licenſe: Let
him be call’d before vs. Away with her to priſon: Goe
too, no more words. Prouoſt, my Brother Angelo will
not be alter’d, Claudio muſt die to morrow: Let him be
furniſh’d with Diuines, and haue all charitable prepara-
tion. If my brother wrought by my pitie, it ſhould not
be ſo with him.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: So pleaſe you, this Friar hath beene with him,
and aduis’d him for th’ entertainment of death.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Good’ euen, good Father.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Bliſſe, and goodneſſe on you.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Of whence are you?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Not of this Countrie, though my chance is now
To vſe it for my time: I am a brother
Of gracious Order, late come from the Sea,
In ſpeciall buſineſſe from his Holineſſe.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: What newes abroad i’th World?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: None, but that there is ſo great a Feauor on
goodneſſe, that the diſſolution of it muſt cure it. No-
ueltie is onely in requeſt, and as it is as dangerous to be
aged in any kinde of courſe, as it is vertuous to be con-
ſtant in any vndertaking. There is ſcarſe truth enough
aliue to make Societies ſecure, but Securitie enough to
make Fellowſhips accurſt: Much vpon this riddle runs
the wiſedome of the world: This newes is old enough,
yet it is euerie daies newes. I pray you Sir, of what diſ-
poſition was the Duke?

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: One, that aboue all other ſtrifes,
Contended eſpecially to know himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: What pleaſure was he giuen to?

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Rather reioycing to ſee another merry, then
merrie at anie thing which profeſt to make him reioice.
A Gentleman of all temperance. But leaue wee him to
his euents, with a praier they may proue proſperous, &
let me deſire to know, how you ﬁnde Claudio prepar’d?
I am made to vnderſtand, that you haue lent him viſita-
tion.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: He profeſſes to haue receiued no ſiniſter mea-
ſure from his Iudge, but moſt willingly humbles him-
ſelfe to the determination of Iuſtice: yet had he framed
to himſelfe (by the inſtruƈtion of his frailty) manie de-
ceyuing promiſes of life, which I (by my good leiſure)
haue diſcredited to him, and now is he reſolu’d to die.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: You haue paid the heauens your Funƈtion, and
the priſoner the verie debt of your Calling. I haue la-
bour’d for the poore Gentleman, to the extremeſt ſhore
of my modeſtie, but my brother-Iuſtice haue I found ſo
ſeuere, that he hath forc’d me to tell him, hee is indeede
Iuſtice.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: If his owne life,
Anſwere the ſtraitneſſe of his proceeding,
It ſhall become him well: wherein if he chance to faile
he hath ſentenc’d himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: I am going to viſit the priſoner, Fare you well.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Peace be with you.
He who the ſword of Heauen will beare,
Should be as holy, as ſeueare:
Patterne in himſelfe to know,
Grace to ſtand, and Vertue go:
More, nor leſſe to others paying,
Then by ſelfe-oﬀences weighing.
Shame to him, whoſe cruell ſtriking,
Kils for faults of his owne liking:
Twice trebble ſhame on Angelo,
To vveede my vice, and let his grow.
Oh, what may Man within him hide,
Though Angel on the outward ſide?
How may likeneſſe made in crimes,
Making praƈtiſe on the Times,
To draw with ydle Spiders ſtrings
Moſt ponderous and ſubſtantiall things?
Craft againſt vice, I muſt applie.
With Angelo to night ſhall lye
His old betroathed (but deſpiſed:)
So diſguiſe ſhall by th’ diſguiſed
Pay with falſhood, falſe exaƈting,
And performe an olde contraƈting.
Take, oh take thoſe lips away,
that ſo ſweetly were forſworne,
And thoſe eyes: the breake of day
lights that doe miſlead the Morne;
But my kiſſes bring againe, bring againe,
Seales of loue, but ſeal’d in vaine, ſeal’d in vaine.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Breake oﬀ thy ſong, and haſte thee quick away,
Here comes a man of comfort, whoſe aduice
Hath often ſtill’d my brawling diſcontent.
I cry you mercie, Sir, and well could wiſh
You had not found me here ſo muſicall.
Let me excuſe me, and beleeue me ſo,
My mirth it much diſpleaſ’d, but pleaſ’d my woe.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: ’Tis good; though Muſick oft hath ſuch a charme
To make bad, good; and good prouoake to harme.
I pray you tell me, hath any body enquir’d for mee here
to day; much vpon this time haue I promiſ’d here to
meete.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: You haue not bin enquir’d after: I haue ſat
here all day.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: I doe conſtantly beleeue you: the time is come
euen now. I ſhall craue your forbearance a little, may be
I will call vpon you anone for ſome aduantage to your
ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: I am alwayes bound to you.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Very well met, and well come:
What is the newes from this good Deputie?

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: He hath a Garden circummur’d with Bricke,
Whoſe weſterne ſide is with a Vineyard back’t;
And to that Vineyard is a planched gate,
That makes his opening with this bigger Key:
This other doth command a little doore,
Which from the Vineyard to the Garden leades,
There haue I made my promiſe, vpon the
Heauy midle of the night, to call vpon him.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: But ſhall you on your knowledge ﬁnd this way?

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: I haue t’ane a due, and wary note vpon’t,
With whiſpering, and moſt guiltie diligence,
In aƈtion all of precept, he did ſhow me
The way twice ore.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Are there no other tokens
Betweene you ’greed, concerning her obſeruance?

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: No: none but onely a repaire ith’ darke,
And that I haue poſſeſt him, my moſt ſtay
Can be but briefe: for I haue made him know,
I haue a Seruant comes with me along
That ſtaies vpon me; whoſe perſwaſion is,
I come about my Brother.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: ’Tis well borne vp.
I haue not yet made knowne to Mariana
A word of this: what hoa, within; come forth,
I pray you be acquainted with this Maid,
She comes to doe you good.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: I doe deſire the like.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Do you perſwade your ſelfe that I reſpeƈt you?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Good Frier, I know you do, and haue found it.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Take then this your companion by the hand
Who hath a ſtorie readie for your eare:
I ſhall attend your leiſure, but make haſte
The vaporous night approaches.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Wilt pleaſe you walke aſide.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Oh Place, and greatnes: millions of falſe eies
Are ſtucke vpon thee: volumes of report
Run with theſe falſe, and moſt contrarious Queſt
Vpon thy doings: thouſand eſcapes of wit
Make thee the father of their idle dreame,
And racke thee in their fancies. Welcome, how agreed?

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Shee’ll take the enterprize vpon her father,
If you aduiſe it.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: It is not my conſent,
But my entreaty too.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Little haue you to ſay
When you depart from him, but ſoft and low,
Remember now my brother.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Feare me not.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Nor gentle daughter, feare you not at all:
He is your husband on a pre-contraƈt:
To bring you thus together ’tis no ſinne,
Sith that the Iuſtice of your title to him
Doth ﬂouriſh the deceit. Come, let vs goe,
Our Corne’s to reape, for yet our Tithes to ſow.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Come hither ſirha; can you cut oﬀ a mans head?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: If the man be a Bachelor Sir, I can:
But if he be a married man, he’s his wiues head,
And I can neuer cut oﬀ a womans head.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Come ſir, leaue me your ſnatches, and yeeld mee
a direƈt anſwere. To morrow morning are to die Clau-
dio and Barnardine: heere is in our priſon a common exe-
cutioner, who in his oﬃce lacks a helper, if you will take
it on you to aſſiſt him, it ſhall redeeme you from your
Gyues: if not, you ſhall haue your full time of impriſon-
ment, and your deliuerance with an vnpittied whipping;
for you haue beene a notorious bawd.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Sir, I haue beene an vnlawfull bawd, time out of
minde, but yet I will bee content to be a lawfull hang-
man: I would bee glad to receiue ſome inſtruƈtion from
my fellow partner.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: What hoa, Abhorſon: where’s Abhorſon there?

speech.speaker: Abh.
speech.line: Doe you call ſir?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Sirha, here’s a fellow will helpe you to morrow
in your execution: if you thinke it meet, compound with
him by the yeere, and let him abide here with you, if not,
vſe him for the preſent, and diſmiſſe him, hee cannot
plead his eſtimation with you: he hath beene a Bawd.

speech.speaker: Abh.
speech.line: A Bawd Sir? ﬁe vpon him, he will diſcredit our
myſterie.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Goe too Sir, you waigh equallie: a feather will
turne the Scale.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Pray ſir, by your good fauor: for ſurely ſir, a
good fauor you haue, but that you haue a hanging look:
Doe you call ſir, your occupation a Myſterie?

speech.speaker: Abh.
speech.line: I Sir, a Miſterie.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Painting Sir, I haue heard ſay, is a Miſterie; and
your Whores ſir, being members of my occupation, v-
ſing painting, do proue my Occupation, a Miſterie: but
what Miſterie there ſhould be in hanging, if I ſhould
be hang’d, I cannot imagine.

speech.speaker: Abh.
speech.line: Sir, it is a Miſterie.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Proofe.

speech.speaker: Abh.
speech.line: Euerie true mans apparrell ﬁts your Theefe.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: If it be too little for your theefe, your true man
thinkes it bigge enough. If it bee too bigge for your
Theefe, your Theefe thinkes it little enough: So euerie
true mans apparrell ﬁts your Theefe.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Are you agreed?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Sir, I will ſerue him: For I do ﬁnde your Hang-
man is a more penitent Trade then your Bawd: he doth
oftner aske forgiueneſſe.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: You ſirrah, prouide your blocke and your Axe
to morrow, foure a clocke.

speech.speaker: Abh.
speech.line: Come on (Bawd) I will inſtruƈt thee in my
Trade: follow.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I do deſire to learne ſir: and I hope, if you haue
occaſion to vſe me for your owne turne, you ſhall ﬁnde
me y’are. For truly ſir, for your kindneſſe, I owe you a
good turne.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Call hether Barnardine and Claudio:
Th’ one has my pitie; not a iot the other,
Being a Murtherer, though he were my brother.
Looke, here’s the Warrant Claudio, for thy death,
’Tis now dead midnight, and by eight to morrow
Thou muſt be made immortall. Where’s Barnardine?

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: As faſt lock’d vp in ſleepe, as guiltleſſe labour,
When it lies ſtarkely in the Trauellers bones,
He will not wake.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Who can do good on him?
Well, go, prepare your ſelfe. But harke, what noiſe?
Heauen giue your ſpirits comfort: by, and by,
I hope it is ſome pardon, or repreeue
For the moſt gentle Claudio. Welcome Father.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: The beſt, and wholſomſt ſpirits of the night,
Inuellop you, good Prouoſt: who call’d heere of late?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: None ſince the Curphew rung.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Not Iſabell?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: No.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: They will then er’t be long.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: What comfort is for Claudio?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: There’s ſome in hope.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: It is a bitter Deputie.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Not ſo, not ſo: his life is paralel’d
Euen with the ſtroke and line of his great Iuſtice:
He doth with holie abſtinence ſubdue
That in himſelfe, which he ſpurres on his powre
To qualiﬁe in others: were he meal’d with that
Which he correƈts, then were he tirrannous,
But this being ſo, he’s iuſt. Now are they come.
This is a gentle Prouoſt, ſildome when
The ſteeled Gaoler is the friend of men:
How now? what noiſe? That ſpirit’s poſſeſt with haſt,
That wounds th’ vnſiſting Poſterne with theſe ſtrokes.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: There he muſt ſtay vntil the Oﬃcer
Ariſe to let him in: he is call’d vp.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Haue you no countermand for Claudio yet?
But he muſt die to morrow?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: None Sir, none.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: As neere the dawning Prouoſt, as it is,
You ſhall heare more ere Morning.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Happely
You ſomething know: yet I beleeue there comes
No countermand: no ſuch example haue we:
Beſides, vpon the verie ſiege of Iuſtice,
Lord Angelo hath to the publike eare
Profeſt the contrarie.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: This is his Lords man.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: And heere comes Claudio’s pardon.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: My Lord hath ſent you this note,
And by mee this further charge;
That you ſwerue not from the ſmalleſt Article of it,
Neither in time, matter, or other circumſtance.
Good morrow: for as I take it, it is almoſt day.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: I ſhall obey him.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: This is his Pardon purchas’d by ſuch ſin,
For which the Pardoner himſelfe is in:
Hence hath oﬀence his quicke celeritie,
When it is borne in high Authority.
When Vice makes Mercie; Mercie’s ſo extended,
That for the faults loue, is th’ oﬀender friended.
Now Sir, what newes?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: I told you:
Lord Angelo (be-like) thinking me remiſſe
In mine Oﬃce, awakens mee
With this vnwonted putting on, methinks ſtrangely:
For he hath not vs’d it before.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Pray you let’s heare.

line.recite: Whatſoeuer you may heare to the contrary, let Claudio be ex-
ecuted by foure of the clocke, and in the afternoone Bernar-
dine: For my better ſatisfaƈtion, let mee haue Claudios
head ſent me by ﬁue. Let this be duely performed with a
thought that more depends on it, then we muſt yet deliuer.
Thus faile not to doe your Oﬃce, as you will anſwere it at

speech.line: What ſay you to this Sir?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: What is that Barnardine, who is to be execu-
ted in th’ afternoone?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: A Bohemian borne: But here nurſt vp & bred,
One that is a priſoner nine yeeres old.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: How came it, that the abſent Duke had not
either deliuer’d him to his libertie, or executed him? I
haue heard it was euer his manner to do ſo.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: His friends ſtill wrought Repreeues for him:
And indeed his faƈt till now in the gouernment of Lord
Angelo, came not to an vndoubtfull proofe.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: It is now apparant?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Moſt manifeſt, and not denied by himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Hath he borne himſelfe penitently in priſon?
How ſeemes he to be touch’d?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: A man that apprehends death no more dread-
fully, but as a drunken ſleepe, careleſſe, wreakleſſe, and
feareleſſe of what’s paſt, preſent, or to come: inſenſible
of mortality, and deſperately mortall.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: He wants aduice.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: He wil heare none: he hath euermore had the li-
berty of the priſon: giue him leaue to eſcape hence, hee
would not. Drunke many times a day, if not many daies
entirely drunke. We haue verie oft awak’d him, as if to
carrie him to execution, and ſhew’d him a ſeeming war-
rant for it, it hath not moued him at all.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: More of him anon: There is written in your
brow Prouoſt, honeſty and conſtancie; if I reade it not
truly, my ancient skill beguiles me: but in the boldnes
of my cunning, I will lay my ſelfe in hazard: Claudio,
whom heere you haue warrant to execute, is no greater
forfeit to the Law, then Angelo who hath ſentenc’d him.
To make you vnderſtand this in a manifeſted eﬀeƈt, I
craue but foure daies reſpit: for the which, you are to
do me both a preſent, and a dangerous courteſie.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Pray Sir, in what?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: In the delaying death.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Alacke, how may I do it? Hauing the houre li-
mited, and an expreſſe command, vnder penaltie, to de-
liuer his head in the view of Angelo? I may make my
caſe as Claudio’s, to croſſe this in the ſmalleſt.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: By the vow of mine Order, I warrant you,
If my inſtruƈtions may be your guide,
Let this Barnardine be this morning executed,
And his head borne to Angelo.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Angelo hath ſeene them both,
And will diſcouer the fauour.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Oh, death’s a great diſguiſer, and you may
adde to it; Shaue the head, and tie the beard, and ſay it
was the deſire of the penitent to be ſo bar’de before his
death: you know the courſe is common. If any thing
fall to you vpon this, more then thankes and good for-
tune, by the Saint whom I profeſſe, I will plead againſt
it with my life.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Pardon me, good Father, it is againſt my oath.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Were you ſworne to the Duke, or to the De-
putie?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: To him, and to his Subſtitutes.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: You will thinke you haue made no oﬀence, if
the Duke auouch the iuſtice of your dealing?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: But what likelihood is in that?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Not a reſemblance, but a certainty; yet ſince
I ſee you fearfull, that neither my coate, integrity, nor
perſwaſion, can with eaſe attempt you, I wil go further
then I meant, to plucke all feares out of you. Looke
you Sir, heere is the hand and Seale of the Duke: you
know the Charraƈter I doubt not, and the Signet is not
ſtrange to you?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: I know them both.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: The Contents of this, is the returne of the
Duke; you ſhall anon ouer-reade it at your pleaſure:
where you ſhall ﬁnde within theſe two daies, he wil be
heere. This is a thing that Angelo knowes not, for hee
this very day receiues letters of ſtrange tenor, perchance
of the Dukes death, perchance entering into ſome Mo-
naſterie, but by chance nothing of what is writ. Looke,
th’ vnfolding Starre calles vp the Shepheard; put not
your ſelfe into amazement, how theſe things ſhould be;
all diﬃculties are but eaſie vvhen they are knowne. Call
your executioner, and oﬀ with Barnardines head: I will
giue him a preſent ſhrift, and aduiſe him for a better
place. Yet you are amaz’d, but this ſhall abſolutely re-
ſolue you: Come away, it is almoſt cleere dawne.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: I am as well acquainted heere, as I was in our
houſe of profeſſion: one would thinke it vvere Miſtris
Ouer-dons owne houſe, for heere be manie of her olde
Cuſtomers. Firſt, here’s yong Mr Raſh, hee’s in for a
commoditie of browne paper, and olde Ginger, nine
ſcore and ſeuenteene pounds, of which hee made ﬁue
Markes readie money: marrie then, Ginger was not
much in requeſt, for the olde Women vvere all dead.
Then is there heere one Mr Caper, at the ſuite of Maſter
Three-Pile the Mercer, for ſome foure ſuites of Peach-
colour’d Satten, which now peaches him a beggar.
Then haue vve heere, yong Dizie, and yong Mr Deepe-
vow, and Mr Copperſpurre, and Mr Starue-Lackey the Ra-
pier and dagger man, and yong Drop-heire that kild lu-
ſtie Pudding, and Mr Forthlight the Tilter, and braue Mr
Shootie the great Traueller, and wilde Halfe-Canne that
ſtabb’d Pots, and I thinke fortie more, all great doers in
our Trade, and are now for the Lords ſake.

speech.speaker: Abh.
speech.line: Sirrah, bring Barnardine hether.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Mr Barnardine, you muſt riſe and be hang’d,
Mr Barnardine.

speech.speaker: Abh.
speech.line: What hoa Barnardine.

speech.speaker: Bar.
speech.line: A pox o’your throats: who makes that noyſe
there? What are you?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Your friends Sir, the Hangman:
You muſt be ſo good Sir to riſe, and be put to death.

speech.speaker: Bar.
speech.line: Away you Rogue, away, I am ſleepie.

speech.speaker: Abh.
speech.line: Tell him he muſt awake,
And that quickly too.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Pray Maſter Barnardine, awake till you are ex-
ecuted, and ſleepe afterwards.

speech.speaker: Ab.
speech.line: Go in to him, and fetch him out.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: He is comming Sir, he is comming: I heare his
Straw ruſſle.

speech.speaker: Abh.
speech.line: Is the Axe vpon the blocke, ſirrah?

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Verie readie Sir.

speech.speaker: Bar.
speech.line: How now Abhorſon?
What’s the newes vvith you?

speech.speaker: Abh.
speech.line: Truly Sir, I would deſire you to clap into your
prayers: for looke you, the Warrants come.

speech.speaker: Bar.
speech.line: You Rogue, I haue bin drinking all night,
I am not ﬁtted for’t.

speech.speaker: Clo.
speech.line: Oh, the better Sir: for he that drinkes all night,
and is hanged betimes in the morning, may ſleepe the
ſounder all the next day.

speech.speaker: Abh.
speech.line: Looke you Sir, heere comes your ghoſtly Fa-
ther: do we ieſt now thinke you?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Sir, induced by my charitie, and hearing how
haſtily you are to depart, I am come to aduiſe you,
Comfort you, and pray with you.

speech.speaker: Bar.
speech.line: Friar, not I: I haue bin drinking hard all night,
and I will haue more time to prepare mee, or they ſhall
beat out my braines with billets: I will not conſent to
die this day, that’s certaine.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Oh ſir, you muſt: and therefore I beſeech you
Looke forward on the iournie you ſhall go.

speech.speaker: Bar.
speech.line: I ſweare I will not die to day for anie mans per-
ſwaſion.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: But heare you:

speech.speaker: Bar.
speech.line: Not a word: if you haue anie thing to ſay to me,
come to my Ward: for thence will not I to day.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Vnﬁt to liue, or die: oh grauell heart.
After him (Fellowes) bring him to the blocke.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Now Sir, how do you ﬁnde the priſoner?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: A creature vnpre-par’d, vnmeet for death,
And to tranſport him in the minde he is,
Were damnable.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Heere in the priſon, Father,
There died this morning of a cruell Feauor,
One Ragozine, a moſt notorious Pirate,
A man of Claudio’s yeares: his beard, and head
Iuſt of his colour. What if we do omit
This Reprobate, til he were wel enclin’d,
And ſatisﬁe the Deputie with the viſage
Of Ragozine, more like to Claudio?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Oh, ’tis an accident that heauen prouides:
Diſpatch it preſently, the houre drawes on
Preﬁxt by Angelo: See this be done,
And ſent according to command, whiles I
Perſwade this rude wretch willingly to die.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: This ſhall be done (good Father) preſently:
But Barnardine muſt die this afternoone,
And how ſhall we continue Claudio,
To ſaue me from the danger that might come,
If he were knowne aliue?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Let this be done,
Put them in ſecret holds, both Barnardine and Claudio,
Ere twice the Sun hath made his iournall greeting
To yond generation, you ſhal ﬁnde
Your ſafetie manifeſted.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: I am your free dependant.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Quicke, diſpatch, and ſend the head to Angelo
Now wil I write Letters to Angelo,
(The Prouoſt he ſhal beare them) whoſe contents
Shal witneſſe to him I am neere at home:
And that by great Iniunƈtions I am bound
To enter publikely: him Ile deſire
To meet me at the conſecrated Fount,
A League below the Citie: and from thence,
By cold gradation, and weale-ballanc’d forme.
We ſhal proceed with Angelo.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Heere is the head, Ile carrie it my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Conuenient is it: Make a ſwift returne,
For I would commune with you of ſuch things,
That want no eare but yours.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Ile make all ſpeede.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Peace hoa, be heere.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: The tongue of Iſabell. She’s come to know,
If yet her brothers pardon be come hither:
But I will keepe her ignorant of her good,
To make her heauenly comforts of diſpaire,
When it is leaſt expeƈted.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Hoa, by your leaue.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Good morning to you, faire, and gracious
daughter.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: The better giuen me by ſo holy a man,
Hath yet the Deputie ſent my brothers pardon?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: He hath releaſd him, Iſabell, from the world,
His head is oﬀ, and ſent to Angelo.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Nay, but it is not ſo.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: It is no other,
Shew your wiſedome daughter in your cloſe patience.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Oh, I wil to him, and plucke out his eies.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: You ſhal not be admitted to his ſight.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Vnhappie Claudio, wretched Iſabell,
Iniurious world, moſt damned Angelo.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: This nor hurts him, nor proﬁts you a iot,
Forbeare it therefore, giue your cauſe to heauen.
Marke what I ſay, which you ſhal ﬁnde
By euery ſillable a faithful veritie.
The Duke comes home to morrow: nay drie your eyes,
One of our Couent, and his Confeſſor
Giues me this inſtance: Already he hath carried
Notice to Eſcalus and Angelo,
Who do prepare to meete him at the gates,
There to giue vp their powre: If you can pace your wiſdome,
In that good path that I would wiſh it go,
And you ſhal haue your boſome on this wretch,
Grace of the Duke, reuenges to your heart,
And general Honor.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: I am direƈted by you.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: This Letter then to Friar Peter giue,
’Tis that he ſent me of the Dukes returne:
Say, by this token, I deſire his companie
At Mariana’s houſe to night. Her cauſe, and yours
Ile perfeƈt him withall, and he ſhal bring you
Before the Duke; and to the head of Angelo
Accuſe him home and home. For my poore ſelfe,
I am combined by a ſacred Vow,
And ſhall be abſent. Wend you with this Letter:
Command theſe fretting waters from your eies
With a light heart; truſt not my holie Order
If I peruert your courſe: whoſe heere?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Good’ euen;
Frier, where’s the Prouoſt?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Not within Sir.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Oh prettie Iſabella, I am pale at mine heart, to
ſee thine eyes ſo red: thou muſt be patient; I am faine
to dine and ſup with water and bran: I dare not for my
head ﬁll my belly. One fruitful Meale would ſet mee
too’t: but they ſay the Duke will be heere to Morrow.
By my troth Iſabell I lou’d thy brother, if the olde fan-
taſtical Duke of darke corners had bene at home, he had
liued.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Sir, the Duke is marueilous little beholding
to your reports, but the beſt is, he liues not in them.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Friar, thou knoweſt not the Duke ſo wel as I
do: he’s a better woodman then thou tak’ſt him for.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Well: you’l anſwer this one day. Fare ye well.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Nay tarrie, Ile go along with thee,
I can tel thee pretty tales of the Duke.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: You haue told me too many of him already ſir
if they be true: if not true, none were enough.

speech.speaker: Lucio.
speech.line: I was once before him for getting a Wench
with childe.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Did you ſuch a thing?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Yes marrie did I; but I was faine to forſwear it,
They would elſe haue married me to the rotten Medler.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Sir your company is fairer then honeſt, reſt you
well.

speech.speaker: Lucio.
speech.line: By my troth Ile go with thee to the lanes end:
if baudy talke oﬀend you, wee’l haue very litle of it: nay
Friar, I am a kind of Burre, I ſhal ſticke.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Euery Letter he hath writ, hath diſuouch’d other.

speech.speaker: An.
speech.line: In moſt vneuen and diſtraƈted manner, his aƈtions
ſhow much like to madneſſe, pray heauen his wiſedome
bee not tainted: and why meet him at the gates and re-
liuer our authorities there?

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: I gheſſe not.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: And why ſhould wee proclaime it in an howre
before his entring, that if any craue redreſſe of iniuſtice,
they ſhould exhibit their petitions in the ſtreet?

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: He ſhowes his reaſon for that: to haue a diſpatch
of Complaints, and to deliuer vs from deuices heere-
after, which ſhall then haue no power to ſtand againſt
vs.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Well: I beſeech you let it bee proclaim’d be-
times i’th’ morne, Ile call you at your houſe: giue notice
to ſuch men of ſort and ſuite as are to meete him.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: I ſhall ſir: fareyouwell.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Good night.
This deede vnſhapes me quite, makes me vnpregnant
And dull to all proceedings. A deﬂowred maid,
And by an eminent body, that enforc’d
The Law againſt it? But that her tender ſhame
Will not proclaime againſt her maiden loſſe,
How might ſhe tongue me? yet reaſon dares her no,
For my Authority beares of a credent bulke,
That no particular ſcandall once can touch
But it confounds the breather. He ſhould haue liu’d,
Saue that his riotous youth with dangerous ſenſe
Might in the times to come haue ta’ne reuenge
By ſo receiuing a diſhonor’d life
With ranſome of ſuch ſhame: would yet he had liued.
Alack, when once our grace we haue forgot,
Nothing goes right, we would, and we would not.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Theſe Letters at ﬁt time deliuer me,
The Prouoſt knowes our purpoſe and our plot,
The matter being a foote, keepe your inſtruƈtion
And hold you euer to our ſpeciall drift,
Though ſometimes you doe blench from this to that
As cauſe doth miniſter: Goe call at Flauia’s houſe,
And tell him where I ſtay: giue the like notice
To Valencius, Rowland, and to Craſſus,
And bid them bring the Trumpets to the gate:
But ſend me Flauius ﬁrſt.

speech.speaker: Peter.
speech.line: It ſhall be ſpeeded well.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: I thank thee Varrius, thou haſt made good haſt,
Come, we will walke: There’s other of our friends
Will greet vs heere anon: my gentle Varrius.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: To ſpeake ſo indireƈtly I am loath,
I would ſay the truth, but to accuſe him ſo
That is your part, yet I am aduis’d to doe it,
He ſaies, to vaile full purpoſe.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Be rul’d by him.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Beſides he tells me, that if peraduenture
He ſpeake againſt me on the aduerſe ſide,
I ſhould not thinke it ſtrange, for ’tis a phyſicke
That’s bitter, to ſweet end.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: I would Frier Peter

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Oh peace, the Frier is come.

speech.speaker: Peter.
speech.line: Come I haue found you out a ſtand moſt ﬁt,
Where you may haue ſuch vantage on the Duke
He ſhall not paſſe you:
Twice haue the Trumpets ſounded.
The generous, and graueſt Citizens
Haue hent the gates, and very neere vpon
The Duke is entring:
Therefore hence away.

scene.stagedir: Enter Duke, Varrius, Lords, Angelo, Eſculus, Lucio, Citizens at ſeuerall doores.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: My very worthy Coſen, fairely met,
Our old, and faithfull friend, we are glad to ſee you.

speech.speaker: Ang. Eſc.
speech.line: Happy returne be to your royall grace.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Many and harty thankings to you both:
We haue made enquiry of you, and we heare
Such goodneſſe of your Iuſtice, that our ſoule
Cannot but yeeld you forth to publique thankes
Forerunning more requitall.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: You make my bonds ſtill greater.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Oh your deſert ſpeaks loud, & I ſhould wrong it
To locke it in the wards of couert boſome
When it deſerues with charaƈters of braſſe
A forted reſidence ’gainſt the tooth of time,
And razure of obliuion: Giue we your hand
And let the Subieƈt ſee, to make them know
That outward curteſies would faine proclaime
Fauours that keepe within: Come Eſcalus,
You muſt walke by vs, on our other hand:
And good ſupporters are you.

speech.speaker: Peter.
speech.line: Now is your time
Speake loud, and kneele before him.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Iuſtice, O royall Duke, vaile your regard
Vpon a wrong’d (I would faine haue ſaid a Maid)
Oh worthy Prince, diſhonor not your eye
By throwing it on any other obieƈt,
Till you haue heard me, in my true complaint,
And giuen me Iuſtice, Iuſtice, Iuſtice, Iuſtice.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Relate your wrongs;
In what, by whom? be briefe:
Here is Lord Angelo ſhall giue you Iuſtice,
Reueale your ſelfe to him.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Oh worthy Duke,
You bid me ſeeke redemption of the diuell,
Heare me your ſelfe: for that which I muſt ſpeake
Muſt either puniſh me, not being beleeu’d,
Or wring redreſſe from you:
Heare me: oh heare me, heere.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: My Lord, her wits I feare me are not ﬁrme:
She hath bin a ſuitor to me, for her Brother
Cut oﬀ by courſe of Iuſtice.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: By courſe of Iuſtice.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: And ſhe will ſpeake moſt bitterly, and ſtrange.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Moſt ſtrange: but yet moſt truely wil I ſpeake,
That Angelo’s forſworne, is it not ſtrange?
That Angelo’s a murtherer, is’t not ſtrange?
That Angelo is an adulterous thiefe,
An hypocrite, a virgin violator,
Is it not ſtrange? and ſtrange?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Nay it is ten times ſtrange?

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: It is not truer he is Angelo,
Then this is all as true, as it is ſtrange;
Nay, it is ten times true, for truth is truth
To th’ end of reckning.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Away with her: poore ſoule
She ſpeakes this, in th’ inﬁrmity of ſence.

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: Oh Prince, I coniure thee, as thou beleeu’ſt
There is another comfort, then this world,
That thou negleƈt me not, with that opinion
That I am touch’d with madneſſe: make not impoſſible
That which but ſeemes vnlike, ’tis not impoſſible
But one, the wickedſt caitiﬀe on the ground
May ſeeme as ſhie, as graue, as iuſt, as abſolute:
As Angelo, euen ſo may Angelo
In all his dreſſings, caraƈts, titles, formes,
Be an arch-villaine: Beleeue it, royall Prince
If he be leſſe, he’s nothing, but he’s more,
Had I more name for badneſſe.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: By mine honeſty
If ſhe be mad, as I beleeue no other,
Her madneſſe hath the oddeſt frame of ſenſe,
Such a dependancy of thing, on thing,
As ere I heard in madneſſe.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Oh gracious Duke
Harpe not on that; nor do not baniſh reaſon
For inequality, but let your reaſon ſerue
To make the truth appeare, where it ſeemes hid,
And hide the falſe ſeemes true.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Many that are not mad
Haue ſure more lacke of reaſon:
What would you ſay?

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: I am the Siſter of one Claudio,
Condemnd vpon the Aƈt of Fornication
To looſe his head, condemn’d by Angelo,
I, (in probation of a Siſterhood)
Was ſent to by my Brother; one Lucio
As then the Meſſenger.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: That’s I, and’t like your Grace:
I came to her from Claudio, and deſir’d her,
To try her gracious fortune with Lord Angelo,
For her poore Brothers pardon.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: That’s he indeede.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: You were not bid to ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: No, my good Lord,
Nor wiſh’d to hold my peace.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: I wiſh you now then,
Pray you take note of it: and when you haue
A buſineſſe for your ſelfe: pray heauen you then
Be perfeƈt.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I warrant your honor.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: The warrant’s for your ſelfe: take heede to’t.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: This Gentleman told ſomewhat of my Tale.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Right.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: It may be right, but you are i’the wrong
To ſpeake before your time: proceed,

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: I went
To this pernicious Caitiﬀe Deputie.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: That’s ſomewhat madly ſpoken.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Pardon it,
The phraſe is to the matter.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Mended againe: the matter: proceed.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: In briefe, to ſet the needleſſe proceſſe by:
How I perſwaded, how I praid, and kneel’d,
How he refeld me, and how I replide
(For this was of much length) the vild concluſion
I now begin with griefe, and ſhame to vtter.
He would not, but by gift of my chaſte body
To his concupiſcible intemperate luſt
Releaſe my brother; and after much debatement,
My ſiſterly remorſe, confutes mine honour,
And I did yeeld to him: But the next morne betimes,
His purpoſe ſurfetting, he ſends a warrant
For my poore brothers head.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: This is moſt likely.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Oh that it were as like as it is true.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: By heauen (fond wretch) ӳ knowſt not what thou ſpeak’ſt,
Or elſe thou art ſuborn’d againſt his honor
In hatefull praƈtiſe: ﬁrſt his Integritie
Stands without blemiſh: next it imports no reaſon,
That with ſuch vehemency he ſhould purſue
Faults proper to himſelfe: if he had ſo oﬀended
He would haue waigh’d thy brother by himſelfe,
And not haue cut him oﬀ: ſome one hath ſet you on:
Confeſſe the truth, and ſay by whoſe aduice
Thou cam’ſt heere to complaine.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: And is this all?
Then oh you bleſſed Miniſters aboue
Keepe me in patience, and with ripened time
Vnfold the euill, which is heere wrapt vp
In countenance: heauen ſhield your Grace from woe,
As I thus wrong’d, hence vnbeleeued goe.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: I know you’ld faine be gone: An Oﬃcer:
To priſon with her: Shall we thus permit
A blaſting and a ſcandalous breath to fall,
On him ſo neere vs? This needs muſt be a praƈtiſe:
Who knew of your intent and comming hither?

speech.speaker: Iſa.
speech.line: One that I would were heere, Frier Lodowick.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: A ghoſtly Father, belike:
Who knowes that Lodowicke?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: My Lord, I know him, ’tis a medling Fryer,
I doe not like the man: had he been Lay my Lord,
For certaine words he ſpake againſt your Grace
In your retirment, I had ſwing’d him ſoundly.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Words againſt mee? this ’a good Fryer belike
And to ſet on this wretched woman here
Againſt our Subſtitute: Let this Fryer be found.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: But yeſternight my Lord, ſhe and that Fryer
I ſaw them at the priſon: a ſawcy Fryar,
A very ſcuruy fellow.

speech.speaker: Peter.
speech.line: Bleſſed be your Royall Grace:
I haue ſtood by my Lord, and I haue heard
Your royall eare abus’d: ﬁrſt hath this woman
Moſt wrongfully accus’d your Subſtitute,
Who is as free from touch, or ſoyle with her
As ſhe from one vngot.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: We did beleeue no leſſe.
Know you that Frier Lodowick that ſhe ſpeakes of?

speech.speaker: Peter.
speech.line: I know him for a man diuine and holy,
Not ſcuruy, nor a temporary medler
As he’s reported by this Gentleman:
And on my truſt, a man that neuer yet
Did (as he vouches) miſ-report your Grace.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: My Lord, moſt villanously, beleeue it.

speech.speaker: Peter.
speech.line: Well: he in time may come to cleere himſelfe;
But at this inſtant he is ſicke, my Lord:
Of a ſtrange Feauor: vpon his meere requeſt
Being come to knowledge, that there was complaint
Intended ’gainſt Lord Angelo, came I hether
To ſpeake as from his mouth, what he doth know
Is true, and falſe: And what he with his oath
And all probation will make vp full cleare
Whenſoeuer he’s conuented: Firſt for this woman,
To iuſtiﬁe this worthy Noble man
So vulgarly and perſonally accus’d,
Her ſhall you heare diſproued to her eyes,
Till ſhe her ſelfe confeſſe it.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Good Frier, let’s heare it:
Doe you not ſmile at this, Lord Angelo?
Oh heauen, the vanity of wretched fooles.
Giue vs ſome ſeates, Come coſen Angelo,
In this I’ll be impartiall: be you Iudge
Of your owne Cauſe: Is this the Witnes Frier?
Firſt, let her ſhew your face, and after, ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Pardon my Lord, I will not ſhew my face
Vntill my husband bid me.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: What, are you married?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: No my Lord.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Are you a Maid?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: No my Lord.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: A Widow then?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Neither, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Why you are nothing then: neither Maid, Wi-
dow, nor Wife?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: My Lord, ſhe may be a Puncke: for many of
them, are neither Maid, Widow, nor Wife.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Silence that fellow: I would he had ſome cauſe
to prattle for himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Well my Lord.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: My Lord, I doe confeſſe I nere was married,
And I confeſſe beſides, I am no Maid,
I haue known my husband, yet my husband
Knowes not, that euer he knew me.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: He was drunk then, my Lord, it can be no better.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: For the beneﬁt of ſilence, would thou wert ſo to.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Well, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: This is no witneſſe for Lord Angelo.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Now I come to’t, my Lord.
Shee that accuſes him of Fornication,
In ſelfe-ſame manner, doth accuſe my husband,
And charges him, my Lord, with ſuch a time,
When I’le depoſe I had him in mine Armes
With all th’ eﬀeƈt of Loue.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Charges ſhe moe then me?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Not that I know.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: No? you ſay your husband.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Why iuſt, my Lord, and that is Angelo,
Who thinkes he knowes, that he nere knew my body,
But knows, he thinkes, that he knowes Iſabels.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: This is a ſtrange abuſe: Let’s ſee thy face.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: My husband bids me, now I will vnmaske.
This is that face, thou cruell Angelo
Which once thou ſworſt, was worth the looking on:
This is the hand, which with a vowd contraƈt
Was faſt belockt in thine: This is the body
That tooke away the match from Iſabell,
And did ſupply thee at thy garden-houſe
In her Imagin’d perſon.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Know you this woman?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Carnallie ſhe ſaies.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Sirha, no more.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Enough my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: My Lord, I muſt confeſſe, I know this woman,
And ﬁue yeres ſince there was ſome ſpeech of marriage
Betwixt my ſelfe, and her: which was broke oﬀ,
Partly for that her promis’d proportions
Came ſhort of Compoſition: But in chiefe
For that her reputation was diſ-valued
In leuitie: Since which time of ﬁue yeres
I neuer ſpake with her, ſaw her, nor heard from her
Vpon my faith, and honor.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Noble Prince,
As there comes light from heauen, and words frō breath,
As there is ſence in truth, and truth in vertue,
I am aﬃanced this mans wife, as ſtrongly
As words could make vp vowes: And my good Lord,
But Tueſday night laſt gon, in’s garden houſe,
He knew me as a wife. As this is true,
Let me in ſafety raiſe me from my knees,
Or elſe for euer be conﬁxed here
A Marble Monument.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: I did but ſmile till now,
Now, good my Lord, giue me the ſcope of Iuſtice,
My patience here is touch’d: I doe perceiue
Theſe poore informall women, are no more
But inſtruments of ſome more mightier member
That ſets them on. Let me haue way, my Lord
To ﬁnde this praƈtiſe out.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: I, with my heart,
And puniſh them to your height of pleaſure.
Thou fooliſh Frier, and thou pernicious woman
Compaƈt with her that’s gone: thinkſt thou, thy oathes,
Though they would ſwear downe each particular Saint,
Were teſtimonies againſt his worth, and credit
That’s ſeald in approbation? you, Lord Eſcalus
Sit with my Cozen, lend him your kinde paines
To ﬁnde out this abuſe, whence ’tis deriu’d.
There is another Frier that ſet them on,
Let him be ſent for.

speech.speaker: Peter.
speech.line: Would he were here, my Lord, for he indeed
Hath ſet the women on to this Complaint;
Your Prouoſt knowes the place where he abides,
And he may fetch him.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Goe, doe it inſtantly:
And you, my noble and well-warranted Coſen
Whom it concernes to heare this matter forth,
Doe with your iniuries as ſeemes you beſt
In any chaſtiſement; I for a while
Will leaue you; but ſtir not you till you haue
Well determin’d vpon theſe Slanderers.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: My Lord, wee’ll doe it throughly: Signior Lu-
cio, did not you ſay you knew that Frier Lodowick to be a
diſhoneſt perſon?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Cucullus non facit Monachum, honeſt in nothing
but in his Clothes, and one that hath ſpoke moſt villa-
nous ſpeeches of the Duke.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: We ſhall intreat you to abide heere till he come,
and inforce them againſt him: we ſhall ﬁnde this Frier a
notable fellow.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: As any in Vienna, on my word.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Call that ſame Iſabell here once againe, I would
ſpeake with her: pray you, my Lord, giue mee leaue to
queſtion, you ſhall ſee how Ile handle her.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Not better then he, by her owne report.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Say you?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Marry ſir, I thinke, if you handled her priuately
She would ſooner confeſſe, perchance publikely ſhe’ll be
aſham’d.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: I will goe darkely to worke with her.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: That’s the way: for women are light at mid-
night.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Come on Miſtris, here’s a Gentlewoman,
Denies all that you haue ſaid.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: My Lord, here comes the raſcall I ſpoke of,
Here, with the Prouoſt.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: In very good time: ſpeake not you to him, till
we call vpon you.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Mum.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Come Sir, did you ſet theſe women on to ſlan-
der Lord Angelo? they haue confeſ’d you did.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: ’Tis falſe.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: How? Know you where you are?

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Reſpeƈt to your great place; and let the diuell
Be ſometime honour’d, for his burning throne.
Where is the Duke? ’tis he ſhould heare me ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: The Duke’s in vs: and we will heare you ſpeake,
Looke you ſpeake iuſtly.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Boldly, at leaſt. But oh poore ſoules,
Come you to ſeeke the Lamb here of the Fox;
Good night to your redreſſe: Is the Duke gone?
Then is your cauſe gone too: The Duke’s vniuſt,
Thus to retort your manifeſt Appeale,
And put your triall in the villaines mouth,
Which here you come to accuſe.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: This is the raſcall: this is he I ſpoke of.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Why thou vnreuerend, and vnhallowed Fryer:
Is’t not enough thou haſt ſuborn’d theſe women,
To accuſe this worthy man? but in foule mouth,
And in the witneſſe of his proper eare,
To call him villaine; and then to glance from him,
To th’ Duke himſelfe, to taxe him with Iniuſtice?
Take him hence; to th’ racke with him: we’ll towze you
Ioynt by ioynt, but we will know his purpoſe:
What? vniuſt?

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Be not ſo hot: the Duke dare
No more ſtretch this ﬁnger of mine, then he
Dare racke his owne: his Subieƈt am I not,
Nor here Prouinciall: My buſineſſe in this State
Made me a looker on here in Vienna,
Where I haue ſeene corruption boyle and bubble,
Till it ore-run the Stew: Lawes, for all faults,
But faults ſo countenanc’d, that the ſtrong Statutes
Stand like the forfeites in a Barbers ſhop,
As much in mocke, as marke.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Slander to th’ State:
Away with him to priſon.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: What can you vouch againſt him Signior Lucio?
Is this the man you did tell vs of?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: ’Tis he, my Lord: come hither goodman bald-
pate, doe you know me?

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: I remember you Sir, by the ſound of your voice,
I met you at the Priſon, in the abſence of the Duke.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Oh, did you ſo? and do you remember what you
ſaid of the Duke.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Moſt notedly Sir.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Do you ſo Sir: And was the Duke a ﬂeſh-mon-
ger, a foole, and a coward, as you then reported him
to be?

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: You muſt (Sir) change perſons with me, ere you
make that my report: you indeede ſpoke ſo of him, and
much more, much worſe.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Oh thou damnable fellow: did I not plucke thee
by the noſe, for thy ſpeeches?

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: I proteſt, I loue the Duke, as I loue my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Harke how the villaine would cloſe now, after
his treaſonable abuſes.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: Such a fellow is not to be talk’d withall: Away
with him to priſon: Where is the Prouoſt? away with
him to priſon: lay bolts enough vpon him: let him ſpeak
no more: away with thoſe Giglets too, and with the o-
ther confederate companion.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Stay Sir, ſtay a while.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: What, reſiſts he? helpe him Lucio.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Come ſir, come ſir, come ſir: foh ſir, why you
bald-pated lying raſcall: you muſt be hooded muſt you?
ſhow your knaues viſage with a poxe to you: ſhow your
ſheepe-biting face, and be hang’d an houre: will’t
not oﬀ?

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Thou art the ﬁrſt knaue, that ere mad’ſt a Duke.
Firſt Prouoſt, let me bayle theſe gentle three:
Sneake not away Sir, for the Fryer, and you,
Muſt haue a word anon: lay hold on him.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: This may proue worſe then hanging.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: What you haue ſpoke, I pardon: ſit you downe,
We’ll borrow place of him; Sir, by your leaue:
Ha’ſt thou or word, or wit, or impudence,
That yet can doe thee oﬃce? If thou ha’ſt
Rely vpon it, till my tale be heard,
And hold no longer out.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: Oh, my dread Lord,
I ſhould be guiltier then my guiltineſſe,
To thinke I can be vndiſcerneable,
When I perceiue your grace, like powre diuine,
Hath look’d vpon my paſſes. Then good Prince,
No longer Seſſion hold vpon my ſhame,
But let my Triall, be mine owne Confeſſion:
Immediate ſentence then, and ſequent death,
Is all the grace I beg.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Come hither Mariana,
Say: was’t thou ere contraƈted to this woman?

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: I was my Lord.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Goe take her hence, and marry her inſtantly.
Doe you the oﬃce (Fryer) which conſummate,
Returne him here againe: goe with him Prouoſt.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: My Lord, I am more amaz’d at his diſhonor,
Then at the ſtrangeneſſe of it.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Come hither Iſabell,
Your Frier is now your Prince: As I was then
Aduertyſing, and holy to your buſineſſe,
(Not changing heart with habit) I am ſtill,
Atturnied at your ſeruice.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Oh giue me pardon
That I, your vaſſaile, haue imploid, and pain’d
Your vnknowne Soueraigntie.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: You are pardon’d Iſabell:
And now, deere Maide, be you as free to vs.
Your Brothers death I know ſits at your heart:
And you may maruaile, why I obſcur’d my ſelfe,
Labouring to ſaue his life: and would not rather
Make raſh remonſtrance of my hidden powre,
Then let him ſo be loſt: oh moſt kinde Maid,
It was the ſwift celeritie of his death,
Which I did thinke, with ſlower foot came on,
That brain’d my purpoſe: but peace be with him,
That life is better life paſt fearing death,
Then that which liues to feare: make it your comfort,
So happy is your Brother.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: I doe my Lord.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: For this new-maried man, approaching here,
Whoſe ſalt imagination yet hath wrong’d
Your well defended honor: you muſt pardon
For Mariana’s ſake: But as he adiudg’d your Brother,
Being criminall, in double violation
Of ſacred Chaſtitie, and of promiſe-breach,
Thereon dependant for your Brothers life,
The very mercy of the Law cries out
Moſt audible, euen from his proper tongue.
An Angelo for Claudio, death for death:
Haſte ſtill paies haſte, and leaſure, anſwers leaſure;
Like doth quit like, and Meaſure ſtill for Meaſure:
Then Angelo, thy fault’s thus manifeſted;
Which though thou would’ſt deny, denies thee vantage.
We doe condemne thee to the very Blocke
Where Claudio ſtoop’d to death, and with like haſte.
Away with him.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Oh my moſt gracious Lord,
I hope you will not mocke me with a husband?

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: It is your husband mock’t you with a husband,
Conſenting to the ſafe-guard of your honor,
I thought your marriage ﬁt: elſe Imputation,
For that he knew you, might reproach your life,
And choake your good to come: For his Poſſeſſions,
Although by confutation they are ours;
We doe en-ſtate, and widow you with all,
To buy you a better husband.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Oh my deere Lord,
I craue no other, nor no better man.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Neuer craue him, we are deﬁnitiue.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Gentle my Liege.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: You doe but looſe your labour.
Away with him to death: Now Sir, to you.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Oh my good Lord, ſweet Iſabell, take my part,
Lend me your knees, and all my life to come,
I’ll lend you all my life to doe you ſeruice.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Againſt all ſence you doe importune her,
Should ſhe kneele downe, in mercie of this faƈt,
Her Brothers ghoſt, his paued bed would breake,
And take her hence in horror.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Iſabell:
Sweet Iſabel, doe yet but kneele by me,
Hold vp your hands, ſay nothing: I’ll ſpeake all.
They ſay beſt men are moulded out of faults,
And for the moſt, become much more the better
For being a little bad: So may my husband.
Oh Iſabel: will you not lend a knee?

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: He dies for Claudio’s death.

speech.speaker: Iſab.
speech.line: Moſt bounteous Sir.
Looke if it pleaſe you, on this man condemn’d,
As if my Brother liu’d: I partly thinke,
A due ſinceritie gouerned his deedes,
Till he did looke on me: Since it is ſo,
Let him not die: my Brother had but Iuſtice,
In that he did the thing for which he dide.
For Angelo, his Aƈt did not ore-take his bad intent,
And muſt be buried but as an intent
That periſh’d by the way: thoughts are no ſubieƈts
Intents, but meerely thoughts.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Meerely my Lord.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: Your ſuite’s vnproﬁtable: ſtand vp I ſay:
I haue bethought me of another fault.
Prouoſt, how came it Claudio was beheaded
At an vnuſuall howre?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: It was commanded ſo.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Had you a ſpeciall warrant for the deed?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: No my good Lord: it was by priuate meſſage.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: For which I doe diſcharge you of your oﬃce,
Giue vp your keyes.

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: Pardon me, noble Lord,
I thought it was a fault, but knew it not,
Yet did repent me after more aduice,
For teſtimony whereof, one in the priſon
That ſhould by priuate order elſe haue dide,
I haue reſeru’d aliue.

speech.speaker: Duk.
speech.line: What’s he?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: His name is Barnardine.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: I would thou hadſt done ſo by Claudio:
Goe fetch him hither, let me looke vpon him.

speech.speaker: Eſc.
speech.line: I am ſorry, one ſo learned, and ſo wiſe
As you, Lord Angelo, haue ſtil appear’d,
Should ſlip ſo groſſelie, both in the heat of bloud
And lacke of temper’d iudgement afterward.

speech.speaker: Ang.
speech.line: I am ſorrie, that ſuch ſorrow I procure,
And ſo deepe ſticks it in my penitent heart,
That I craue death more willingly then mercy,
’Tis my deſeruing, and I doe entreat it.

scene.stagedir: Enter Barnardine and Prouoſt, Claudio, Iulietta.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Which is that Barnardine?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: This my Lord.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: There was a Friar told me of this man.
Sirha, thou art ſaid to haue a ſtubborne ſoule
That apprehends no further then this world,
And ſquar’ſt thy life according: Thou’rt condemn’d,
But for thoſe earthly faults, I quit them all,
And pray thee take this mercie to prouide
For better times to come: Frier aduiſe him,
I leaue him to your hand. What muﬀeld fellow’s that?

speech.speaker: Pro.
speech.line: This is another priſoner that I ſau’d,
Who ſhould haue di’d when Claudio loſt his head,
As like almoſt to Claudio, as himſelfe.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: If he be like your brother, for his ſake
Is he pardon’d, and for your louelie ſake
Giue me your hand, and ſay you will be mine,
He is my brother too: But ﬁtter time for that:
By this Lord Angelo perceiues he’s ſafe,
Methinkes I ſee a quickning in his eye:
Well Angelo, your euill quits you well.
Looke that you loue your wife: her worth, worth yours
I ﬁnde an apt remiſſion in my ſelfe:
And yet heere’s one in place I cannot pardon,
You ſirha, that knew me for a foole, a Coward,
One all of Luxurie, an aſſe, a mad man:
Wherein haue I ſo deſeru’d of you
That you extoll me thus?

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: ’Faith my Lord, I ſpoke it but according to the
trick: if you will hang me for it you may: but I had ra-
ther it would pleaſe you, I might be whipt.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Whipt ﬁrſt, ſir, and hang’d after.
Proclaime it Prouoſt round about the Citie,
If any woman wrong’d by this lewd fellow
(As I haue heard him ſweare himſelfe there’s one
whom he begot with childe) let her appeare,
And he ſhall marry her: the nuptiall ﬁniſh’d,
Let him be whipt and hang’d.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: I beſeech your Highneſſe doe not marry me to
a Whore: your Highneſſe ſaid euen now I made you a
Duke, good my Lord do not recompence me, in making
me a Cuckold.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Vpon mine honor thou ſhalt marrie her.
Thy ſlanders I forgiue, and therewithall
Remit thy other forfeits: take him to priſon,
And ſee our pleaſure herein executed.

speech.speaker: Luc.
speech.line: Marrying a punke my Lord, is preſſing to death,
Whipping and hanging.

speech.speaker: Duke.
speech.line: Slandering a Prince deſerues it.
She Claudio that you wrong’d, looke you reſtore.
Ioy to you Mariana, loue her Angelo:
I haue confes’d her, and I know her vertue.
Thanks good friend, Eſcalus, for thy much goodneſſe,
There’s more behinde that is more gratulate.
Thanks Prouoſt for thy care, and ſecrecie,
We ſhall imploy thee in a worthier place.
Forgiue him Angelo, that brought you home
The head of Ragozine for Claudio’s,
Th’ oﬀence pardons it ſelfe. Deere Iſabell,
I haue a motion much imports your good,
Whereto if you’ll a willing eare incline;
What’s mine is yours, and what is yours is mine.
So bring vs to our Pallace, where wee’ll ſhow
What’s yet behinde, that meete you all ſhould know.

personae.persnames: The names of all the Aƈtors.
